Ha T. T. N. (id:010114060004) was born in 1974. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to breed poultry.

Mai T. N. (id:010114060005) was born in 1969. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to invest in her restaurant.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Thoa's Group

texts.en:
Thoa T. N. (id: 010114150032) was born in 1958 and lives in L. Phap village with her husband and three sons. She is a farmer: she breeds pigs and poultry. Beside that, she buys scrap iron  to sell. She has a monthly income of about 2,000,000 VND from this job. Her first son is married and her two younger sons help her to earn money.

Thoa T. N. wants to earn a lot of money to buy more furniture. She has taken part in SEDA for five years and has repaid on time. She is very happy because she is abL. to save money every day.

This time, Thoa T. N. wants to borrow 7,194,000 VND (approximately 385 USD) for her small business and to buy feed for her pigs.

About the other borrower in her group:

Nhi T. L. (id: 010114150031) was born in 1955.  She buys scrap iron to sell. She wants to borrow 5,886,000 VND(approximately 315 USD) to invest in her small business.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business and to purchase pig feed

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Danaya est composé de cinq  femmes mariées majoritairement dans  des grandes familles traditionnelles, avec en moyenne 34ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent le village de Téssérèla chef lieu d’une commune rurale de la préfecture de Barouéli (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage et de voisinage. 
Elles sont à leur 1er prêt solidaire et vendent des  articles divers et des céréales. 
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 5 sacs de riz, 14 sacs de mil, 10 sacs d’arachide en gousse, 1sac de gombo séché, 3 cartons de savons de lessive et ½ de sac savon local « Gabacourouni ». 
Elles s’approvisionnent à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou, sur place à Téssérèla, dans les villages environnants et à la foire hebdomadaire de N’Gassola.  La vente de ces produits se fait à domicile, aux foires hebdomadaires de  N’Gassola et Téssérèla  au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 32 200FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les prêts de Soro Yiriwaso, acheter des petits ruminants et participer aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes et funérailles).
texts.en:
The Danaya group is made up of five women, married for the most part into traditional extended families, and are on average 34 years old with five children. They live in Téssérèla, the head village of a rural community, part of the Barouéli prefecture (4th administrative region of Mali). They got acquainted through marriage and family ties, and as neighbors. They are requesting a first group loan, to retail various items and grain cereals. The loan will be used to buy: five bags of rice, 14 bags of millet, 10 bags of unshelled peanuts, one bag of dried gombo, three cases of laundry detergent and ½ bag of local «Gabacourouni» soap. They get their supplies from the weekly Segou and N’Gassola market fairs, and locally in Téssérèla. They retail their products from their homes, at the weekly market fairs in N’Gassola and Téssérèla, for cash or credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They hope to attain average monthly earnings of 32,200 FCFA each, part of which will be used to reimburse the Soro Yiriwaso loan, and the remainder to buy small livestock and participate in social events (weddings, baptisms and funerals).

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: June

texts.en:
Jane is a 40-year-old single mother of two who has been selling second-hand clothes for the last five years. She is a former employee of Kenya Bereau Limited (KBL).

Jane appreciates Faulu Kenya for helping her with three loans which have improved her business, hence earning more profit. She wants a loan of Kes 40,000 to add to her stock of clothes. She hopes to increase her sales so as to improve her income.

In ten years time, Jane wants to be in her own permanent shop. She describes herself as hardworking and ambitious.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Benkadi  sont mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames avec en moyenne 49 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Ouélégana : région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de mariage et font essentiellement la vente de produits alimentaires.
Elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursé le premier. 
Ce prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 200 sacs de feuilles de baobab, 150kg de mil et 100kg de potasse alimentaire. 
Elles se ravitaillent dans les villages de Benzena, Wessebougou, Donzana et Sonkebougou et effectuent leurs ventes au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle mixte, à domicile, en ambulant et aux marchés de Ségou. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 19.000FCA qui sera utilisé pour l’achat des condiments, les soins de santé et de scolarisation des enfants. 
Elles ont pour ambitions l’achat des matériels agricoles dans ce partenariat avec Soro /Kiva
texts.en:
The six women of the Benkadi group are married, the majority living in polygamous families. They have an average age of 49 years old and an average of four children. They all live in the village of Ouélégana in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They got to know each other through neighbors, relatives and marriage, and their principal activity is selling food products. They are on their second group loan, having repaid the first without any problem. This loan will be used to buy 200 bags of baobab (monkey bread tree) leaves, 150 kg of millet and 100kg of edible potash. They get their supplies in the villages of Benzena, Wessebougou, Donzana and Sonkebougou, and sell for cash and on credit to a mixed customer base, at home, walking around and at the markets in Ségou. They envisage making an average monthly profit of 19,000 FCA which will be used to buy condiments, and to cover health care and the children's schooling costs. Their ambition is to buy agricultural equipment in partnership with Soro/Kiva.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a 29-year-old single man. He has been running a cafeteria for three years and has one employee. He was previously involved in the transport business.

Charles appreciates Faulu Kenya for training him in record keeping. He previously took out two loans which he used to improve his business.

Charles has requested Kes 35,000 from Faulu Kenya so as to add to his stock of food products like wheat flour, maize flour, rice, cooking fat and other products for cooking in his cafeteria.

Charles hopes to expand his cafeteria in the future.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs for his cafeteria

loans.name: Myagmar

texts.en:
Myagmar is 48 years old and lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her husband live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. They have two children who live near their home. Myagmar's daughter and son help a lot with their parent's business. Generally, they have a great family atmosphere.

Myagmar operates a dairy trading business from a rental counter at a local trading center called Saruul. She sells eggs, ham and dumplings. Myagmar moved to Ulaanbaatar from the countryside in 2003 and has been running her dairy business since 2008.

Recently, Myagmar has started operating a grocery store and has been working hard to accumulate enough money to buy a retail space of her own. She is a very hardworking person who has great communication skills.

Myagmbar is focused on the future and says, “My dream is to purchase an apartment for my family.” She is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase a variety of food products for her grocery store business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of food products for her grocery store

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya est composé de cinq  femmes mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles polygames, avec en moyenne 45ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Ouélégana : région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali). 
 Dans le souci d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce elles décidèrent d’intégrer le programme et sont à leur 7ème  prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursé les six  premiers. 
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 150 sacs de feuilles de baobab, 10 bassines de tomates, 15 sacs d’oignon, 200kg de poisson fumé et séché, un sac de jujubes et 2 sacs d’arachide. Elles se ravitaillent en marchandises dans la foire de Tonan et dans les villages de Wessebougou, Donzana. Elles revendent leurs marchandises au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle mixte, à domicile, en ambulant dans les foires de Tonan, Cinzana village, Banankoro village et aux marchés de Ségou. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.000FCA qui sera utilisé pour l’achat des condiments et les soins de santé.
texts.en:
The Danaya group is made up of five married women, the majority of whom live in large traditional polygamous families. They have an average age of 45 years old and an average of five children. They all live in the village of Oélégana in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). In order to increase their business they decided to join the loan programme and are on their seventh group loan, having repaid the six previous loans. This loan will be used to buy 150 bags of baobab (monkey bread tree) leaves, ten bowls of tomatoes, 15 bags of onions, 200kg of smoked and dried fish, a bag of "jujubes" (the fruit from the jujuba tree) and two bags of peanuts. They get their supplies at the fair in Tonan and in the villages of Wessebougou and Donzana. They resell their goods for cash and on credit to a mixed customer base, at home, and walking through the fairs at Tonan, Cinzana village and Banankora village, as well as in Ségou's markets. They envisage making an average monthly profit of 30,000 FCA which will be used to buy condiments and cover healthcare.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Mornica

texts.en:
Mornica is married and has children who depend on her. She grows and sells farm products such as cereals, milk and fruit to wholesalers, friends and neighbors from her farm. Her husband is a mason. He works hard to take care of his family and support his wife’s business.

Since she joined Faulu Kenya, Mornica has been saving her money and she has been able to buy a cow. Her wish is to offer higher and better education to her children. She has requested a loan of Kes 25,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy a dairy cow.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Gizelle

texts.en:
Gizelle is 45 years old, married and the mother of three children. Since 2002, she has made a living by owning a chocolate shop. She produces chocolates and makes designs and decorations for all kind of ceremonies, including weddings, baptisms, engagements, births and more. She is well known across the region for delicious sweets as well as beautiful and varied designs. 

Gizelle has applied for a loan for $1,000 to redesign her shop in order to attract new clients and increase her business productivity and her family's income.

loans.use: To refurnish her chocolate shop

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 50 years of age. She is widowed and has three children who attend school and are dependent on her.

Mary runs a greengrocery where she sells vegetables and cereals to the area residents. She also practices farming to earn more profits. She was previously hawking (selling door-to-door) plastic items before she started this business.

Since she became a member of Faulu, Mary has been able to take out loans of Kes 58,000. She plans to expand her business by opening other branches in the future.

Mary has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to pay school fees and provide necessities for her children.

Mary’s wish is to see her children accomplish their careers and be professionals.

loans.use: To pay school fees and provide necessities for her children

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob is a 29-year-old married man with three children, two of whom attend school.

It is two years now since Jacob started his own school. He employs three teachers to teach in the school. He earns extra income from selling sweet potatoes. He was previously employed before he invested his money in this business.

Jacob plans to invest more in his school to enlarge it and to buy a plot in the future. He has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 to buy office equipment and desks.

loans.use: To buy office equipment and desks

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bashiran's Group

texts.en:
Bashiran baji is a 49-year-old married lady. She is an uneducated lady because her parents were very poor and could hardly meet their financial expenses. This situation never made her feel disappointed at any time because she lives with the belief that although she never got much in her life her own kids will get all they need. She is a mother of three kids: two sons and one daughter. All of her kids are enrolled in a school and getting an education. 

Bashiran's husband's name is M. R. and he is a cook by profession and runs his own food corner in the community. His food is based on Punjabi dishes such as “Daal Chawal" and "Dahi Bhalas”.  He selected this dishes because there’s a tendency in Pakistani people  to prefer to eat Punjabi dishes rather than others. His business is going well and he earns Pak rupees 10,000 to 15,000 in a month. 

Bashiran is a very supportive lady. She helps her husband in his business, which gives him strength to work harder. Bashiran’s brother also lives with her and works in a factory, receiving a meager income. She knows that her brother is very hard-working and he is wasting his strength by doing an ordinary job. Therefore Bashiran has decided for him to start a timber-selling business. To start a business she requires a loan of Pak Rs. 15000 so he will be able to buy lumber in bulk.  

Bashiran is also a group leader for four other women from her community. Tahira M. wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Kanizan baji wants a loan to buy goats for her animal-selling business. Lalan baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart. Kosar baji wants a loan to buy mason's tools. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Bashiran baji is seated first on the left and all the other baji’s are helping Tahira baji who is seated front right, arranging the plants.

loans.use: To start a lumber-selling business

loans.name: Saudah

texts.en:
Saudah is a 40-year-old married woman with seven children aged between 6 months and 21 years. Six of her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and owns a six-roomed house where she lives with ten people. The family doesn’t have access to electricity or piped water.

Saudah fries samosas (fried or baked triangular-shaped pastry shells with a savory filling), chapattis (unleavened flatbread, similar to tortillas) and kebab (pieces of meat roasted or grilled on a skewer or spit). She uses public transport to and from shopping and incurs extra transport costs while distributing her samosas, selling to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. She also distributes to different shops and schools nearby.

Saudah buys wheat flour, cooking oil and baking powder from Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala. She works seven days a week and, on average, she receives about forty customers a day.

Saudah works in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business seventeen years and with MCDT for eight years. She is servicing her seventeenth loan working with the same group members.

Saudah’s monthly expenses include feeding the family, school fees and medication. Her business challenges include the expenses of cartons of wheat flour and jerrycans of cooking oil.

Saudah is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and to start buying directly from manufacturers.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of baking flour and jerrycans of cooking oil

loans.name: Thaer

texts.en:
Thaer is 44 years old, married and has three children. For the last 12 years, he has made a living owning a bakery and a small café where he sells Lebanese breads and other food products. His wife helps him with his business and with meeting the demands of the customers. 

Thaer has requested a loan of $1,200 to buy a new machine to make dough. The machine will increase his productivity and, with it, his income.

loans.use: to buy a new bread-making machine

loans.name: Naseem Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
This is Naseem Akhtar and she is a 35 years old and married lady. She lives in the city named Chichawatni in Pakistan, a city famous for its sweetmeats. Her husband is the same age as her, and his name is M. H.. He is a very talented man. He has the skill of sewing clothes and he can drive vehicles as well. He runs his own tailoring shop where he stitches women's clothes specifically. Naseem Akhtar helps him by sewing clothes to complete the orders of his customers. Naseem learned the skill of sewing clothes from her mother and it has given her a good advantage today. My husband appreciates how she share his work load. 

Now the two of them have decided to start another business because M. H. always has had a wish to buy his own vehicle, but due to having no capital he developed an interest in the tailoring business. Naseem has requested a loan of Pak Rs. 15000 which will be a great help to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

Note: Naseem akhtar baji is seated second from the left with her sewing machine and the other women are seated around her, showing clothes she made.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled  motor vehicle)

loans.name: White C Group

texts.en:
M. A., age 44, is married and has two children aged 11 and 9. He has owned and operated a general store since 2001, working from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily. From this business Matthew is able to earn a monthly profit of about $270.

This will be M.’s fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, his previous loans, all repaid, having been used to increase his store stock and open another store for his wife. He now hopes to obtain a loan to buy a small plot of land.

M. will share this loan with his subgroup C of White group, whose six members sell food and have retail and general stores. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. In the picture, M. is in the front with a white t-shirt

loans.use: To buy a small plot of land

loans.name: Mastula

texts.en:
Mastula is a 50-year-old widowed mother of seven children aged between 38 and 17 years, three of whom attend school while the rest are working. She is being helped by her elder brother to pay school fees for the school-going children. Mastula resides in a rented one-room house where she is staying with three people. Mastula doesn’t take care of any additional family members. There is no electricity or piped water at her home, but the family gets three meals a day.

Mastula resides in Kalerwe, a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala where she sells vegetables and fruits including avocados, tomatoes, and onions from a rented stall. Working two days a week, she sells to an average of 30 people a day. Mastula’s major monthly expenses include rent for the home and business premises, school fees and medication. She incurs extra transport costs to and from villages to collect her produce. She has been in this business for the past 20 years, her main challenge being the rainy season as the village roads then become impassable.

Mastula has been with MCDT for over six years and is now requesting her 24th loan, working all the time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying more boxes of avocados, onions and tomatoes for her business. Mastula aspires to build rental rooms on the plot of land she bought from previous loans. .

loans.use: To buiy more boxes of avocados, onions and tomatoes

loans.name: Shamshad's Group

texts.en:
Shamshad Baji is a mature, 27-year-old married lady. She has two sons who are not of school-going age yet. Her husband's name is L. A. and he is one year older than his wife. He fulfills the duties of a mason. He has been in this profession for the past 10 years. He gets orders from builders and earns income. 

Shamshad Baji is a lady who values hard-working people. She believes that her husband is one of them. So to share his financial burden she makes artificial flowers and decoration pieces on order. Her husband appreciates her and respects her for her kind thoughts. Shamshad is applying for a loan to buy mason's tools for her husband so that he can efficiently perform his work and doesn't have to borrow tools from others.

Shamshad has in her group two other women. Zubaida baji and Kalsoom baji each want a loan to buy mason's tools for their husbands.


Note: Shamshad Baji is seated in the middle of the two women.

loans.use: To buy mason's tools

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Mamadou Kanté est âgé de 39 ans et vit dans une famille monogame avec son enfant et sa femme dans le quartier Banankabougou, sous préfecture de Fana, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Monsieur Mamadou abandonna  très vite l’école pour s’intéresser aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce d’articles divers. Kanté s’est spécialisé dans l’achat vente des ingrédients entant dans la fabrication des savons traditionnels. Mamadou Kanté est très sollicité et jouit d’une grande notoriété dans la ville de Fana et environs. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son deuxième prêt individuel, après  avoir correctement  remboursé le premier.
Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, des barriques de soude caustiques et des bidons d’huile de palme rouge. 
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale du Mali) pour venir les revendre dans sa boutique sise au grand marché de Fana, en détail au comptant  et souvent à crédit, à une clientèle composée de fabricantes de savons traditionnels appelé  ‘’Gabakourouni’’.
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 80.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour les dépenses de la famille et le reste investi dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou Kanté, aged 39, lives in a monogamous family with his child and wife in the Banankabougou district, sub-prefecture of Fana (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  He quickly dropped out of school to pursue income-generating work, particularly commerce in a variety of goods.  He became specialized in buying and selling the ingredients for making traditional soaps.  He is in high demand and enjoys great fame in and around Fana City.  Concerned about satisfying further his burgeoning customer base, Mamadou decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his second individual loan after having properly repaid the first one.  He intends to use this loan for buying barrels of caustic soda and containers of red palm oil.  He gets his supplies in Bamako (capital of Mali) in order to come and sell them in his shop located at the big market in Fana.  Cash and often credit are accepted from customers composed of makers of traditional soaps called "Gabakourouni’’. Mamadou hopes to make an average monthly profit of 80,000 francs CFA that will be used for family expenses.  The rest will be invested into the business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying palm oil and caustic soda

loans.name: Benjamin Kiptum

texts.en:
Benjamin S., born in 1955, is married to Stella, who is 51 years old and a nursing student in Washington DC. They have seven children aged between 10 years and 30 years old: Caroline, a 30-year-old post graduate student; Edmon, 27 and in university; Sylvia, 23 and a form four graduate; Gilbert, 21 and in University; Cornelius,19 and in form four; Christine Chesire, 15 and in form one, and Jepkurui 10 and in Standard Four.

Benjamin owns residential houses for rental purposes and he also runs a business consultancy firm which he started two years ago. He started the rental business ten years ago and he gets a monthly profit of Kshs 25,000 from all his business sources. His tenants are people who live in Kabarnet Town.

Benjamin was introduced to KADET by existing clients of the organization. He has applied for an education loan which he plans to use to pay school fees for his son Gilbert Kiptoo, who attends Kenyatta University in Kenya. This will not be Mr. Sergons’ first loan as he has a credit history with another institution.

He hopes to make a profit from his business investments and with it he will extend his commercial plot. In the future he hopes to construct more permanent houses for his tenants. Mr S. describes himself as hardworking and creative.

loans.use: He will use the loan to pay school fees for his son

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice O. is 49 years old, married, and has 6 children - 4 boys and 2 girls - who all excel in school. Eunice's husband is a civil servant and also helps with the household work. Eunice herself is a trader, selling foodstuffs like garri (cassava flakes), beans, cooking oil, and fish at retail prices as well as drinks at both retail and wholesale prices. Eunice hopes to see her business expand so that she can support her husband in covering the family's expenses. To this end, Eunice hopes to obtain a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase additional foodstuffs and drinks for sale. She is thankful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs and drinks for sale

loans.name: Zuhran's Group

texts.en:
Zuhran baji is a widow. Her husband died at the age of 58 from a heart attack. This was a big loss for her. He was a very sensible and educated man. He raised his two sons well and gave them good qualifications. Thus, the elder son completed his education till 14th standard and the younger one got his education up to 12th standard. The elder son works in the police department. The other runs a grocery shop at the market. 

Zuhran herself stays at home and takes care of the animals and does domestic chores. She is applying for a loan to buy groceries to expand her son’s grocery shop into a grocery store.

She is the group leader for three other women from her locality. Shazia baji and Hanifan baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops. Razia baji wants a loan to repair her tractor. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Zuhran baji is seated second from the left, cooking.

loans.use: To diversify the business

loans.name: Deme Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe  Deme ont en moyenne  45 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Bouwere, un des villages de  la sous-préfecture de Konobougou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et font le commerce d’articles divers tels l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires, des poissons fumé et séché, des cosmétiques, des céréales, du savon et le miel. Elles font également  de temps à autres des friandises et des galettes à base de mil, de niébé et de riz. 
Après avoir correctement remboursés les  3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Deme sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé, pour constituer un stock de condiments alimentaires et acheter, 2 douzaines de produits cosmétiques, 1 tonne de céréales, 2 cartons de savons et des colis de  poissons séchés. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  à Bamako (capitale du Mali), Mopti, Konobougou et sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes, à Bouwere, au marché de Konobougou ville et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women from the Deme group are on average 45 years old and have an average of four children. They all live in traditional extended families in Bouwere, a village in the sub-prefecture of Konobougou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali) These women met one another through ties of kinship and neighborhood. They sell various articles such as condiments, smoked and dried fish, cosmetics, cereals, soap and honey. From time to time they also make sweets and biscuits made from millet, black-eyed peas and rice. After having fully repaid the three previous loans, the women from the Deme Group are on their fourth group loan which will be used to build up a stock of condiments, and to buy 2 dozens cosmetic products, 1 ton of cereals, 2 boxes of soap and packages of dried fish. They get their goods from Bamako (Capital of Mali), Mopti, Konobougou and locally from growers and wholesalers. They sell their goods in Bouwere, at the Konobougou town market and at the neighboring fairs. They sell for cash, retail and on credit to customers who are made up of women and men. They are each planning on making an average monthly profit of 10, 000 Francs CFA, that will be used for health related expenses, food, and schooling fees. The rest will be reinvested in the activities.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia O. is married, has 6 children, and is also a grandmother. Her husband is a retired forest guard, while Felicia herself works as a trader, selling traditional beads and jewellery at retail prices to customers in Benin city. Nigerians love traditional beads, and they are part of all traditional clothing items. The traditional beads in Nigeria are also a mark of honour and respect. 
Felicia currently hopes to expand her business; however, she faces the challenge of insufficient capital. She is therefore requesting a loan of a NGN 150,000 to purchase additional beads and jewellery items for sale. Felicia is thankful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase of traditional beads and jewellery for sale

loans.name: Sophia Wanjiru

texts.en:
Sophia is 40 years old, married, and has two children. She earns a living farming crops and raising dairy cows, selling the milk to a local dairy society.  The dairy business provides Sophia with sufficient income to cover her family's basic needs, while crop farming provides both food for the family and fodder for the cattle. Also Sophia's husband, Lucas, is a farmer.

Sophia was introduced to KADET through a marketing initiative in Githunguri, a trading center near her home. This is her first loan with KADET, although she has already previously borrowed capital from the Farmers Society to which she sells milk. Sophia plans to use the current loan to prepare and cultivate additional land for crop farming and plant more fodder for the cows.

She hopes to be able to thereby earn enough to buy additional land for farming and build a house with electricity access for her family.

loans.use: Preparation of farmland for planting maize and fodder for dairy animals

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana A. is 60 years old, married, and has 6 children. Her husband is a businessman, selling building materials to help cover the family's expenses. Christiana herself earns income selling crates of drinks at wholesale and retail prices in Benin City. She has been in this business already for a long time and successfully uses her experience for attracting and retaining customers. Christiana has a good relationship with LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organisation) which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Christiana hopes to expand her business and support her family, and is therefore asking for a loan of NGN 150,000 to be able to purchase additional crates of drinks for sale. She is thankful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase of crates of drinks for sale

loans.name: Jeremiah

texts.en:
Jeremiah is 47 years old, married, and has two children, both of whom are grown up and financially independent. His primary business is crop and animal farming, and he has been involved in this activity for the last 22 years. Jeremiah lives and works in Githunguri - an evergreen highland area in central Kenya that receives plenty of rainfall and is therefore particularly favorable for agriculture. Jeremiah's wife Lucy is also involved in business - she sells groceries. 

Jeremiah was introduced to KADET by another member of the organization, and this is his first loan with KADET, although he has already previously borrowed from the farmers society to which he sells milk. Jeremiah plans to use the current loan to purchase and install a water pump as well as buy a tank for water storage. Jeremiah hopes to be able to thereby increase his income to be able to improve the livings standards of his family.

loans.use: Purchase of a water pump and a tank for water storage

loans.name: Bilquis' Group

texts.en:
Bilquis is 51 years old, married with one son. Her son is studying in 9th standard in a local school in Chichawatni. Chichawatni city is famous for its sweetmeats. Bilquis' husband is a farmer. Bilquis requested a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer for her husband to plant his crops and get a high crop yield come harvest time. The income will help support the family, especially in the domains of food, health, and education. 

Bilquis is the group leader for four other women from her locality. Sajida Baji and Majidan Baji each want a loan to buy mason's tools. Arshad Baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Mumtaz Baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. 

Note: Bilquis Baji is seated third from the right and the others are helping with her domestic work.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Mlandizi Kati Group

texts.en:
Sofia H., age 33, is married and has one daughter, who is 1 year old. She has a motorcycle spare parts shop in Mlandizi, which is about 50 kilometers from the city center. She has been in this business since 2000. She works from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily.  From this business, she is able to earn a monthly profit of around $148.

This will be Sofia’s third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, a Kiva partner.  She used the previous loans to buy more spare parts to increase her stock and has paid back the loans successfully. She hopes for a loan to increase her stock still more.
	
Sofia will share this loan with her subgroup of  Mlandizi Kati group, which totals seven members. These members deal in selling vegetables, drinks and clothes and have shops and a boutique. The members of the same group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.  

In the picture, Sofia is the tallest lady.

loans.use: To buy more spare parts

loans.name: Josphine

texts.en:
Josephine is a 40-year-old married lady and mother of six children, who are in primary school and high school. Her primary business is dairy farming, though she also does crop farming on a small scale. She has been doing this for the last 20 years. She sells milk to the dairies and other milk vendors. Her husband, Peter, is a farmer as well.

She got to know about KADET, a Kiva partner, through marketing that was carried out by the organization in Githunguri. This will be her first loan with KADET. She plans to buy animal feed and use the extra profit to buy another cow. With that, she will increase her volume of milk sales.

Josephine hopes to better the livings standards of her family, have electricity fixed in her home and also educate her children through the university level. She considers herself hardworking.

loans.use: Josphine plans to buy animal feed for her cattle worth 20,000 shillings

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella A. is a 33-year-old married mother of three children. Her children attend school and this makes her happy. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports their home. 

Stella has a good relationship with LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organisation, a Kiva partner). LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. 

She sells baby things, clothes, shoes and bags. She has been in this business for a long time and she hopes to expand her business. Stella is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more baby things to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baby things to sell

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe  Sabougnouma  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Dounamakabougou, un des villages de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes  font essentiellement l’achat et la vente de céréales et de condiments alimentaires.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 5 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe  Sabougnouma sont à leur sixième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 1 tonne de céréales sèches (fonio, petit mil, maïs) et une grande quantité  de condiments alimentaires telles les poivres, les oignons, les cubes maggies, les concentrées de tomates, les sels de cuisine, les sounbala.
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes au marché, au comptant, à crédit et en détail, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 12.500FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women in the Sabougnouma group are all married. They average 35 years of age, have an average of four children and live in extended traditional families in Dounamakabougou, one of the villages in Fana, the prefecture of Diolia, the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali. These women primarily buy and sell cereals and condiments. Having repaid five previous loans without problem, the women in the Sabougnouma group are on their sixth group loan, which will be used to buy a ton of dried cereals (fonio, pearl millet, corn) and a large quantity of condiments such as peppers, onions, "Maggi" stock cubes, tomato concentrate, cooking salt and sounbala (a condiment made from "néré" seeds). They get their supplies primarily from local producers and wholesalers, and they sell at the market for cash and on credit, on a retail basis, to a customer base made up of women and men. They envisage making an average monthly profit of 12,500 FCFA each, which will be used to provide for family needs and to invest in their business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals and condiments

loans.name: Bintu

texts.en:
Bintu S. is a businesswoman who lives in New London and owns a provision shop some where in the center of town.  She has fifteen years of experience in business.

Bintu S. is married with four children of whom two are in primary school. She assists her husband greatly in taking care of the children.

Bintu S. has been in a group loan with ARD and has a very good credit history. Because of her hard work and dedication to her business she has decided to apply for an individual loan so that she can buy more stock to meet her customers’ needs.

Bintu S. hopes to use the profit from the business to care for her family and expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To buy Provision

loans.name: Lindah Auma

texts.en:
Lindah Auma M. is a modest single mother of 53 years. She separated from her husband and was left with the responsibility of taking care of their four children aged 11, 8, 7 and 4 years. The first born is in 7th grade of primary school while the last born is in kindergarten.

Lindah operates a clothing business in Migosi Estate, a populous residential area in Kisumu City. She has been in this business for the last eleven years and draws most of her clients from the nearby settlements and other market shoppers.

Lindah is taking her second loan from KADET after repaying well her first loan. It is due to her good credit history that she has been given another loan. She hopes to use the money from the loan to purchase more clothing stock as well as to purchase a new sewing machine since she intends to diversify into dressmaking.

Lindah hopes to expand her business and become a leading supplier of clothing so as to increase her clientele. Being a single mother, she also plans to educate her children to the highest level of education so as to improve their living standard.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine and more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mark

texts.en:
Mark B. K. is a trader who resides in Torpoi town, Bo. He sells used clothes at a well-recognized market area known as Roma Market which is located at old Gerehun Road.

Mark is married with three children and they are all in school.

Mark is seeking a loan buy more stock. He will later use the profit from the business to complete the construction of his house and to educate his children.

loans.use: To buy  used clothing

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Les 4 femmes du groupe Badenya sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 42 ans, 6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles au quartier Fana coura de la ville de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  essentiellement l’achat vente des produits alimentaires tels  les  condiments alimentaires, les fruits et légumes et  les céréales.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les  12 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Badenya sont à leur  13 prêt solidaire.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, 5 tonnes de céréales (haricot mil, maïs, fonio, riz), quelques chargements de charrettes en fruits et légumes et  une quantité importante  de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes à Bamako, Ségou et sur place  au marché de Fana, au comptant en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 60.000FCFA qui servira à étoffer leur fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.
texts.en:
The four women in the Badenya group are all married. They average 42 years of age, have an average of six children and all live in traditional families in the Fana Coura district of the town of Fana, in the prefecture of Dioila, the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali. These women met through relatives and essentially buy and sell food products such as condiments, fruit, vegetables and cereals. Having correctly repaid the previous 12 loans, the women in the Badenya group are on their 13th group loan. They are planning to use this new loan to buy five tons of cereal (bean millet, corn, fonio, rice) several barrow loads of fruit and vegetables and a significant quantity of condiments. They get their supplies primarily from local producers and wholesalers and sell in Bamako, Ségou and locally at the market in Fana, for cash on a retail basis, and on credit, to a customer base made up of women and men. They envisage making an average monthly profit of 60,000FCFA which will be used to boost their business and to cover expenses relating to food, their children's schooling and health.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food products

loans.name: Isaiah

texts.en:
Mr. Isaiah A. was born in 1956. He is married to Loice Kiptoon and they have eight children: Wilson (23 yrs: in college), Jematia (19 yrs: Form four graduate), Kibet (21 yrs: Standard eight), Kipkulei (17 yrs: Standard 7), Kiprop (15 yrs: Standard 6), Cheptumo (13 yrs: Standard 5), Jeruto (10 yrs: Standard 3) and Rutto (8 yrs: Standard 1).

Isaiah runs a timber yard and also practices maize farming. He started this business twenty-nine years ago. He gets a monthly profit of Ksh 3,000 from this business and Ksh 5,000 from other sources of income which include his farm produce.

Isaiah was introduced to KADET by a community leader. He has never borrowed from another source before and this will be his first loan from KADET. He has requested a loan of Ksh 40,000 from KADET of which he plans to use Ksh 10,000 to purchase petrol (gasoline) for the power saw, Ksh 15,000 to plant crops, and the balance to purchase logs for sawing timber.

If this loan boosts his business he will use the extra profit to open a furniture shop. He dreams of opening a sawmill and he describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs, petrol for timber harvesting and logs for sawing lumber

loans.name: Carot Group

texts.en:
Isabela I., age 25, is married with one daughter of three years. She has operated a salon business since 2003. She works from 8.30 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily and she is able to earn a monthly profit of about $114.

This will be Isabela’s 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy more salon equipment and has paid back the loan successfully. She hopes for a new loan to improve further on her salon stock.

Isabela will share this loan with her loan group, Carot, which totals fifteen members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.

In the photo, Isabela is second from left, second row, standing in a colored dress.

loans.use: To buy salon requirements

loans.name: Kolaban Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Kolaban,  toutes mariées,  ont en moyenne 35 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à N’Tjifina sous préfecture de Fana,  Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Les femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce des condiments, de baignés, de la friture de farine de blé et de haricot.
Les femmes du groupe Kolaban sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 1 sac de farine de blé, 2 sacs de 100Kg de la graine de haricot et des condiments.
L’approvisionnent se fait sur place et au marché de Nangola. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Fana ville et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 22.500FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the Kolaban group, who are all married, average 35 years of age, have an average of two children and all live in extended traditional families in N'Tjifina, in the sub-prefecture of Fana in the region of Koulikoro (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women got to know each other through relatives and have a business buying and selling condiments and fritters made from wheat flour and beans. The women of the Kolaban group are on their first group loan which will be used to buy one bag of wheat flour, two 100kg bags of bean seeds and condiments. They get their supplies locally and at the market in Nangola. They sell their products at the market in Fana town and at surrounding fairs, for cash, on a retail basis, and on credit, to a customer base made up of women and men. They envisage making an average monthly profit of 22,500 FCFA each, which will be used for expenses relating to health, food and schooling; the rest will be reinvested in their business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments, wheat flour and beans

loans.name: Betty Nabisubi's Group

texts.en:
Betty is 44 years old and is married with five children aged between 14 and 27 years. Two of her children go to school. Betty also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and owns a twelve-roomed house where she lives with seven people. She doesn’t have electricity or piped water at home.

Betty works seven days a week in a semi-rural area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She has a kiosk in Mulago and has been in this business for twelve years. She doesn't incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work. She sells to all categories of people.

Betty is servicing her third loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more Irish potatoes and cooking oil.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of Irish potatoes and cooking oil

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose D. is a 47-year-old woman from the region of Diourbel, Senegal. She is married and is the mother of five children.

Rose has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NGASCOP for four years and has always paid back her loans on time.

Rose's main activity consists of selling cosmetics products and cloth. Besides this, she also raises pigs to increase her revenues. This loan is used to buy new perfume and fabrics which she will sell.

The revenues generated by this activity allow Rose to pay for the medical and school expenses of her children.

loans.use: To purchase perfume and fabrics to sell

loans.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
This Samina and she lives in a mid-sized city called Vehari, Pakistan. She became a citizen of this city when she married I. M.. He is a government employee, but he has good driving skills also.  She is the mother of two kids: one son and one daughter. Her daughter is two years old and her son is just 8 months old. She got an education up to 10th standard. After that, she wanted to continue her studies but her parents couldn’t afford the expense and so they made her quit. 

Her husband, together with her, knows the value of education so they have decided that they will give their kids a better future. For this reason she sew clothes for her neighbors and saves the money for our kids’ future. 

Her husband is a very hard-working person. Although he has a job, he wants to use his driving skills so that he can earn a lot. Therefore Samina has decided to apply for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) so that they will be able to achieve their plans and make their children proud.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en: Gondoun B. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Is Able. In the photo, he is the one holding the sign. Gondoun is 33 years old, married, and has three children who range from 2 to 10 years old. He was only able to attend school, himself, through high school due to poverty. For two years, Gondoun has been selling foodstuffs such as bread, milk, and sardines at the Thinker’s Village in Paynesville, Liberia. He sells the foodstuffs in a friendly manner, which keeps his customers returning. Gondoun plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more milk, sardines and bread. His goal is to grow his business so that it has branches around town and to build a house for his family to live in. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more milk, sardines and bread to sell

loans.name: Marie Agnése

texts.en:
Marie Agnése N. is 78 years old, married, and lives in the region of Diourbel, Senegal. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NGASCOP for thirteen years and has always paid back her loans on time.

Madame N. raises cattle which she sells at the grand agricultural market of nearby Bambey. With this loan, she plans to buy calves to raise.

loans.use: To purchase calves to raise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase salon materials in bulk

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex S. is married and has five dependents. He has received junior high education.

Alex is a blacksmith and makes hoes, knives, jacks and spears at Elmina. His wife is a hair dresser. Alex uses his income to educate his children and pay for accommodation for the family.

Alex will use the loan to purchase metals to make more hoes and jacks for sale. With the new profits earned as a result of the loan received, Alex plans to expand his business and to increase his farm produce.

loans.use: To purchase metals to make hoes and jacks for sale

loans.name: Sosan's Group

texts.en:
Sosan baji is 52-year-old married lady. She has been a citizen of a city called Vehari, Pakistan for the past 25 years. She is a hard-working lady who works in a hospital. Her husband is a janitor in a school and has 20 years' experience. They built their house with their earnings 10 years ago. They have a single daughter and her name is Nazia. She got her education up to 10th standard and then did a beautician course. Seeing her interest in that field, they have decided to open a beauty parlor for her. Therefore they need a loan to buy the required items such as cosmetics and a hair dryer. 

Sosan is the group leader for three other women from her locality. Asia baji wants a loan to buy lentils, cooking oil and rice for her husband's food-selling business. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to sell. Sabira baji wants a loan to buy repair tools for her motor workshop.


Note: Sosan baji is seated in front on the left and the other members are helping Asia baji who is seated second on the right, sewing clothes.

loans.use: To start a beauty parlor

loans.name: Marie Nicole

texts.en:
Marie Nicole D. is 44 years old and lives in the region of Diourbel, Senegal. She is married and is the mother of six children.

Madame D. has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NGASCOP for thirteen years and has never had problems in paying back her loans. She runs a small shop where she sells mainly vegetables but also a variety of other products.

This loan will be used to buy new vegetables which Madame D. will resell in her shop. The revenues generated by this activity allow her to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase ten 100kg bags of rice

loans.name: Farida S.

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 33-year-old Farida Magalula from Mbarali. She is married with three children between the ages of 3 and 12.

Farida has been running a cafe business. Client’s business is a local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces.

Farida works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, 7 days per week and currently earns about 80 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase more ingredients such as rice, wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil in bulk for business.

In the future, Farida plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support!


About SELFINA: 
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients such as rice, wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil in bulk for business.

loans.name: Augusta

texts.en:
Augusta D. is 50 years old and she is married with four children. Her husband also works to support the home.

Augusta is a petty trader and sells fruits like pawpaw, bananas, pineapples, oranges and mangoes. She started her business four years ago and she hopes to expand her business.

Augusta is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more fruit to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to sell

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is a 42-year-old widow with four children aged between 10 and 16 years. All her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and owns a two-roomed house where she lives with four people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.

Aisha has a poultry farm in Kisaasi counting to a round 650 chickens: 350 broilers and 300 layers. Her major business challenges are thieves and the ever-increasing prices of chicken feeds in Uganda.

Aisha works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week and receives an average of twenty customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. She incurs transport costs to and from buying poultry feeds from Mengo, Kisenyi.

Aisha has been in this business for over fifteen years and with MCDT for ten years. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was easy to work with.

Aisha is servicing her twenty-sixth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of chicken feeds and 100 layer chicks. She is aspiring to owning 1,500 chickens.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of chicken feeds and 100 layer chicks

loans.name: Khoudia

texts.en:
Khoudia D. is a 26-years-old women from the region of Diourbel, Senegal. She is married and is the mother of five children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NGASCOP for three years and has always paid back her loans on time.

Khoudia D. raises sheep which she sells at the grand agricultural market of nearby Bambey. She will use this loan to buy more sheep. The revenues from selling them at the market allow her to improve the living conditions of her young family.

loans.use: To purchase more sheep

loans.name: God Power Group

texts.en:
Mamie S. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Power. In the photo, Mamie is the one holding the sign. She is 32 years old, single, and has five children who range from 5 to 22 years old. She was only able to attend school through 6th grade due to poverty.

For two years, Mamie has been selling rice, milk and biscuits at the Thinker’s Village in Paynesville, Liberia. She sells her goods in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning.

Mamie plans to use her 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 38,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more rice, milk and biscuits to sell. Her goal is to grow her business and build a house for her family.


About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more rice, milk and biscuits to sell

loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk

loans.use: To purchase more rice and beans

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en: Prossy M. is  married woman with six children .  All her children go to school. Prossy owns a three room house where she is staying with eight people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Prossy takes care of additional family members. Prossy has a food stall where she sells such products as bananas, cassava and sweet potatoes. She buys these food stuffs from the Kalerwe Market one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She sells to all categories of people on retail and also offers outside catering. Her monthly expenses include rent for her business premises, school fees for her children and feeding the family. She incurs additional transport costs to and from shopping. Prossy has been in this business for twelve years. Prossy hope to see her business grow bigger and, in the near future,to start selling to  wholesale customers only.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, cassava and sweet potatoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: Augustina A. is 35 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband is a civil servant. She sells ice blocks, drinks, groceries and she also bakes cakes to make a living. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She has been in this business for 3 years. Augustina is a LAPO client. She hopes to grow her business. Augustina needs a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more drinks and groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and groceries

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more soap, sugar, soft drinks and rice in bulk

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.en: Madeleine D. is a 45 year old woman from the region of Diourbel, Senegal. She is married and the mother of six children. Madame D. has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NGASCOP for eight years and has always paid back her loans on time. She sells agricultural products such as peanuts, millet and bissap (a plant that is used to make syrup). Madeleine D. will use this loan to buy more peanuts and millet to resell.

loans.use: To purchase peanuts and millet

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy E. is a LAPO client. She is 45 years old and married with 2 children. Her children are excelling in school and this gives her joy. Mercy’s husband is a business man and he also works in a gas station to support their home.  Mercy sells planks at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for 7 years. Mercy loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers.  Mercy is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more planks to sell.  She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Specioza

texts.en: Specioza M. is 36 years of age and married with four children.  All her children go to school. Specioza rents a six room house and  where she stays with her children. She always has three meals a day and her greatest expense is tuition for her children. Specioza raises chickens for a living. She works seven days a week. She normally receives about ten customers a day and most of her clients are men. She sells poultry on a retail basis. She has had this business for over seven years. In addition to rearing chickens, Specioza is also a shop attendant.The main challenge she faces in her poultry business is that it is seasonal. She only sells her hens when they have matured.  Specioza has been a member with MCDT for six years. She chose to work with MCDT because they operate in a simplified way that is easy for anyone to understand. Specioza wants to use this loan to buy more chicken feed and chicks. She also wants to continue expanding on her business until it becomes a farm.

loans.use: To buy more chicken feed and chicks

loans.name: Edmée Maty

texts.fr: Edmée Maty F. est une femme de 59 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 2 ans et responsable de 2 autres enfants qu'on lui a confiés. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DOUROU-KHOUDOSS depuis juillet 2007 et y a bénéficier de 7 prêts qu'elle a toujours bien gérés et remboursés sans difficultés. Elle est détentrice d'un salon de coiffure et y vend en même temps des effets cosmétiques. Elle participe financièrement à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Edmée Maty F. is a 59-year old woman who is married and has two children of her own; she also has two other children who have been entrusted to her care. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois in DOURU-KHOUDASS since July 2007 and has had seven loans, which she has always managed well and repaid without problem. She owns a hairdressing salon and at the same time sells cosmetics there. She is contributing financially to the improvement in her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Develop and promote her hairdressing salon

loans.name: Eseza

texts.en: Eseza N. is a 39 year old married woman with three children between 4 and 17 years of age.  All her children go to school. Eseza rents a two room house where she is staying with eight people. There is electricity but no piped water at home. Eseza takes care of additional family members.  The family gets two meals a day.  Eseza sells cosmetics in Bwaise. She resides and works in semi urban area on the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week.  She receives 20 customers a day. She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.  The major challenges she faces in her business are monthly rent, medication costs, feeding the family and increasing prices of cosmetics. Eseza has been in this business for eight years and with MCDT for eight years now servicing her eleventh loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more cosmetics and a hair dryer. Eseza is hopeful of seeing her business grow bigger and owning a permanent business structure and her own home.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics and a hair dryer

loans.name: Fe Y Esperanza 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Virginia is the coordinator of her group, Fe y Esperanza (Faith and Hope), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding El Seibo, one of the poorest regions of the Dominican Republic, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and their two children.

Virginia is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza  after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a colmado or small corner store by purchasing rice, cooking oil, white sugar, brown sugar, flour, coffee, potatoes, tuna, salsa and sardines to sell in her store. She will use the profits to invest in her children by purchasing shoes for them as well as in her home where she plans to replace the wooden walls with concrete block. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Rice, cooking oil, white sugar, brown sugar, flour,  coffee, potatoes, tuna, salsa and sardines

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk for her business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a 33-year-old single mother of four children, who are between the ages of 3 and 16. All her children go to school. Josephine resides in and owns a three-roomed house where she is staying with six people. There is no electricity and piped water at home. Josephine takes care of additional family members. The family gets three meals a day. She resides in and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.

Josephine sells second-hand clothes in the Bwaise Market. She works seven days a week. She receives 12 customers a day. She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping. The major challenges she faces in her business are monthly market dues, medication, thieves, feeding the family and the increasing prices of clothes. 

Besides this clothing business, she also sells fruits. Josephine has been in this business for four years and with Kiva partner MCDT for five years. She is servicing her 11th loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of clothes. Josephine aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business structure.

loans.use: To buy more second-hand clothes

loans.name: Vero

texts.en: Vero is 52 years old and married with 2 children. Her husband is a transporter and he also supports their home. Vero sells building materials like sharp sand, granite and blocks. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. She has been in this business for 3 years. Vero is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more building materials to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk.

loans.name: Dibor

texts.fr: Dibor S. est une femme de 57 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants et a la charge d'un autre enfants qui lui a été confié. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis juillet 2007 et a de bonnes expériences avec le crédit pour en avoir bénéficier 7 fois de suite. Elle fait essentiellement l'élevage de poulets de chaire mais développe aussi un petit commerce de fournitures scolaires. Son activité lui procure des bénéfices lui permettant de s'équiper en meubles (lit et armoire) et de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Dibor S. is a 57-year-old woman who is married and the mother of five children.  Plus, she has another child entrusted to her.  Dibor has been a member of Banc Villageois since July 2007 and has a good record as a borrower for having benefited from seven consecutive loans.  She essentially raises fryer chickens but is also developing a small business involving school supplies.  Her business brings in profits allowing her to have furniture (bed and armoire) and to take part in improving her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Developing her business further in raising chickens

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is a LAPO client. Elizabeth sells planks at retail prices to her customers; she has been in this business for 7 years. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is 45 years old and married with 2 children. Her children are excelling in school and this gives her joy. Elizabeth’s husband is a carpenter and he also works to support their home. She is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more planks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell.

loans.name: Lucinda Esther

texts.es:
La Sra. Lucinda, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Moralinas”, del Distrito de Morales, Región y Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviente, tiene 56 años y 03 hijos todos independientes.

Lucinda, antes se dedicaba a vender golosinas con su primer crédito de 300 Nuevos Soles compró, su horno a gas y moldes para poner los kekes, motivada por su esposo e hijos emprendió su propio negocio de ventas de kekes lo que ella misma los prepara, utilizando su horno a gas, reparte a las bodegas de su ciudad, cuenta con clientela fija, amigos del barrio,  vecinos y moradores 

Con este préstamo de S/2,000.00 Nuevos Soles comprará, azúcar en sacos, harina, mantequilla en kilos, huevos en javas, leche en cajas, esencia de vainilla en botellas de un litro, gas en balones y parte del dinero invertirá en comprar moldes.

Lucinda, se siente muy orgullosa por su trabajo que realiza día a día, siempre con el apoyo de su esposo, es el quien le da muchos ánimos y fuerzas de seguir adelante,   manifiesta su agradecimiento al Movimiento Manuela R. por darle la oportunidad de crecer como mujer y pequeña empresaria.
texts.en:
Lucinda belongs to “Las Moralinas” Communal Bank in the District of Morales, San Martín Region and Department. She is in a common-law marriage, is 56 years old and has 3 adult children. Lucinda used to sell candy. With her first loan of 300 soles she bought a gas oven and baking pans for making cakes. Motivated by her husband and children, she started her own business selling cakes which she makes herself, using her gas oven. She distributes them to grocery stores in the city and has steady customers including friends, neighbors and residents in the neighborhood. With this loan of 2,000 soles she will buy sacks of sugar, flour, kilos of butter, cartons of eggs, cartons of milk, one-liter bottles of vanilla extract, cylinders of gas, and she will invest part of the money in buying baking pans. Lucinda is very proud of the work she does everyday, always with the support of her husband, who gives her encouragement and strength to move forward. She is grateful to Movimiento Manuela R. for giving her the opportunity to grow as a woman and a small business owner.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of supplies for making cakes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk for business.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is a hard working and friendly woman. Evelyn is married with 6 children. Her husband is an electrician and he also supports the home. She sells foodstuffs such as rice, beans, onions, peppers, melons, groundnut oil, and salts. She has been in this business for a long time. Evelyn is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a three wheel motorcycle to help her transport goods and people.

loans.name: Elisabeth Heriette

texts.fr: Élisabeth Henriette M. est âgée de 31 ans, elle est célibataire et mère d'un enfant en charge et responsable d'un autre qui lui a été confié par ses porches. Elle est membre du banc Villageois de DAROU-KHOUDOSS depuis juillet 2007 et y a reçu 7 prêts qu'elle a toujours bien gérés et remboursés régulièrement. Elle développe une petite unité d'élevage de poulets de chaire. Cette activité lui génère des bénéfices qui lui permettent de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Élisabeth Henriette M. is 31 years old. She is single and mother to one child. In additional to her child, she is responsible for another child who was left on her porch. Élisabeth has been a member of the Banc Villageois of Darou-Khoudoss since July 2007. She has received seven previous loans which she has handled well and repaid regularly. Élisabeth is developing a small livestock of broiler chicken. This work generates funds which allow her to better her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Better development of broiler chicken livestock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk for her business.

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Kate is a LAPO client. She is a fashion designer, and she also sells sarongs, ice blocks, soft drinks, and sachet water. She makes lovely Nigerian and western designs for her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. Kate is 42 years old, she is married with a child, and her husband is a transporter. She hopes to have more children in the future. She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more sarongs and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and drinks to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs in bulk for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more rice in bulk.

loans.use: Purchase products to stock her business.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is a LAPO client. Gladys sells planks at retail prices to her customers; she has been in this business for 4 years. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is 45 years old and married with 3 children. Her children are excelling in school and this gives her joy. Gladys’ husband is a commercial driver and he also works to support their home. She is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more planks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk for business.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.fr: Jacqueline F. est âgée de 44 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DAROU-KHOUDOSS depuis 3ans et demi et y a reçu 7 prêts qui lui ont permis de développer un petit commerce d'huile de palme. Une activité qu'elle mène depuis plus de 3 ans jusqu'à nos jours. Les bénéfices générés par son petit commerce lui permettent de participer à l'amélioration des condition de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Jacqueline F. is 44 years old. She is married and mother to three children. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of Darou-Khoudoss for three and a half years. She has received seven loans which allowed her to develop a small palm oil business, a trade she has worked in for three years. The profits generated from her small business allow her to help better the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her capital to buy and resell palm oil and peanut butter

loans.use: To purchase more rice in bulk.
