loans.use: To purchase more salon items in bulk.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en: Edith is a hard working and friendly woman. She is 45 years old. She is married with 5 children. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports the home. She sells foodstuffs, groceries and drinks. She has been in this business for a long time. Edith is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Capullo De Rosa Group

texts.es:
La señora Ana Q. es tesorera de la asociación comunal  “Capullo de Rosa” del centro focal de Villa Adela, de 42 años de edad, esta casada y tiene 6 hijos.  Como socia ya tiene siete ciclos en la asociación. Su negocio está relacionado con la venta de sábanas y medias por mayor.  Cuando se le consultó sobre cómo inicio su negocio, ella se sonrie y dice “la necesidad”, cuando viajó a Santa Cruz hace varios años con su esposo y ya no tenìan dinero para comer, tuvieron que aprender a vender.  Ahora ella y su esposo continùan trabajando juntos y venden en La Ceja de la ciudad de El Alto y en la calle Tumusla de la ciudad de La Paz.

“Capullo de Rosa” es una asociación que pertenece al centro focal de Villa Adela, cuenta con 13 integrantes, sus negocios son variados:  tienda de barrio, venta de cosméticos, venta de máquina de tejer, costura de fajas, venta de ropa, detergentes, ropa interior y sábanas, papa y chuño, venta de novedades (se comercia el producto de la època, por ejemplo si es navidad puede negociar con juguetes), pensiòn, venta de Tucumanas (empanadas con relleno de gigote de carne o pollo.
texts.en:
Ana Q. is treasuer of focal center Villa Adela's "Capullo de Rosa" (Rosebud) communal bank. She is 42 years old, married and has 6 children. She has had 7 loan cycles as a member of the association. She sells sheets and stockings at wholesale. When asked how she began her business, she smiled and stated that it was due to "need." Several years ago, when she and her husband moved to Santa Cruz, they didn't have money enough left to eat; they had to learn how to sell. Now, she and her husband continue to work together. They sell in La Ceja in El Alto and on Tumusla street in La Paz. "Capullo de Rosa" is an association belonging to the Villa Alta focal center. It has 13 members, who are involved in a variety of commercial activities: neighborhood store, cosmetics sales, sale of a loom, sash making, clothing sales, detergents, underwear and sheets, potato and dehydrated potato, novelty seasonal items (for example, if it's Christmas, it's toy sales), room and board, Tucumanas (minced meat or chicken turnovers).

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheets and stockings.

loans.name: Jaír Javier

texts.es:
Jair Javier V. Beltrán vive en el muy alegre barrio Simón Bolívar de la ciudad de Barranquilla, es comerciante  de electrodomésticos como lavadores, equipos de sonido y televisores. Tiene 15 años de estar negociando estos artículos  y comenzó desde hace 10 años cuando tenía 20 años de edad,  ayudando a su mamá a vender y ahora  fue ella quien lo remitió a la Fundación. Este es su tercer financiamiento  con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y está aplicando a  $1.300.000 que quiere invertir en la compra de equipos de sonido, lavadoras y televisores que le han encargado.
Jair viaja mensualmente a Maicao, una ciudad fronteriza cerca de Venezuela para traer electrodomésticos que le dan una utilidad a su negocio pues conoce muy bien este mercado; el  también tiene a un tío que vive en Aguachica en el departamento de Cesar a quien envía electrodomésticos por encomienda y Jair va una vez al mes a este municipio a traer el dinero producto de su venta. Las utilidades que ha recibido con los créditos otorgados por la Fundación, le han servido para ayudar al sostenimiento del hogar donde vive junto a sus padres y una abuela: su mamá tiene un negocio y su papá trabaja en la soldadura y reparaciones de canecas de aluminio en una empresa que se envasa la leche.
El sueño de Jair es que su negocio crezca incluso en otros municipios a través del mismo sistema de encomienda. También tiene una meta de tener una casa propia. A Jair le gusta mucho el fútbol y es un asiduo juniorista (entusiasta por Junior, el equipo de fútbol de Barranquilla).
texts.en:
Jair Javier V. Beltrán lives in Barranquilla’s very cheerful Simón Bolívar neighborhood. He is a home appliance merchant. He sells such items as: washing machines, sound systems and television sets. He has been in this line of work for 15 years. He started 10 years ago, when he was 20 years old, helping his mother sell; it was she who sent him to the Fundación. This is his third loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and he is asking for $1.300.000 to buy sound systems, washing machines and television sets that he has pending orders for. Jair travels monthly to Maicao, a city on the border with Venezuela, to bring appliances that produce good profits for his business; he knows this market very well. He also has an uncle that lives in Aguachica, Cesar department, to whom he sends appliances on consignment. Jair travels to this city once a month to collect earnings from his sales. The profits he has earned through loans from the Fundación have helped him to support his home where he lives with his parents and grandmother. His mother has a business and his father works as a welder repairing aluminum trash bins for a milk bottling plant. Jair’s dream is that his business expands into other municipalities through his consignment system. He also has as a goal to have his own home. Jair loves football and is an avid Juniorista (fan of Junior, Barranquilla’s team).

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sound systems, washing machines and television sets.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more sugar, salt, maize flour, cooking oil, beans in bulk.

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
La Sra. María Elena, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Moralinas”, del Distrito de Morales, Región y Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 51 años, y es madre de 05 hijos todos independientes.
María Elena, su seguridad y perseverancia le llevo a iniciar  su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes en general , ubicada en su casa un espacio amplio y acondicionado para  atender a sus clientes que diariamente acuden a comprar .Con  su primer préstamo de 
S/. 300.00 Nuevos Soles, implemento más su negocio comprando, leche en cajas, conservas de pescado, aceite en litros y otros.  
Con este préstamo de S/1,500.00 Nuevos Soles comprara más productos, como aceites, fideos, leche, arroz y azúcar en sacos, galletas dulces y saladas en cajas y parte del dinero lo invirtió en  bebidas gasificadas cómo gaseosas y agua mineral en docenas, para su surtir su negocio.
María Elena, se siente con muchas ganas de seguir trabajando y esta muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades de desarrollarse en el medio donde se desenvuelven
texts.en:
Maria Elena is a member of the community bank "Las Moralinas" of the Morales district, region and department of San Martin. She is 51 years old, is married and is the mother of 5 children who are all independent. Maria Elena's security and perseverance led to start her own business selling groceries. Her store is located in her home in a spacious and conditioned space where she is able to attend to her clients daily. With her first loan of 300 Nuevos Soles (PEN) she implemented her business further by buying more products such as oils, pastas, milk and sugar in sacks, cookies and crackers. She invested part of the money in soft drinks and mineral water to stock her business. Maria Elena is eager to keep working and is very thankful to Movimiento Manuela Ramos for allowing women like her to have opportunities in a medium where they can develop.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase groceries to stock her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase the quantity of stock in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia is a hard working and friendly woman. She is a widow with 5 children. Life as a widow has not been easy for her, but she is coping well. She sells foodstuffs and soup ingredients at retail prices to her customers. She sells for long hours to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and soup ingredients to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and soup ingredients to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more spare parts in bulk.

loans.name: Teresa De Jesús

texts.es:
Teresa D. Jesús Márraga tiene 59 años vive en la ciudadela 20 D. Julio D. Barranquilla tiene 5 hijos en las edades  desD.  30 a 39 años, se dedica a la venta D. mercancía y también D. alimentos,  especialmente almuerzos  y dulces, para lo cual solicita a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, su crédito número 15, por valor D.  $ 2.000.000, con él comprará mercancía como ropa, calzado, prendas y electrodomésticos  para satisfacer la demanda D. su clientela.
Proveniente D. SabanagranD. desD. sus 20 años D. edad , estudio hasta tercer  grado D. primaria y no pudo continuar, porque cuando su padre murió,  cuatro D. sus seis hermanas tuvieron que dedicarse a trabajar D. empleadas del servicio domestico para sostener el hogar; pero un día su madre le propuso hacer un negocio y tomó su experiencia en la preparación D. alimentos e inició la venta D. pasteles y almuerzos  hasta el día D. hoy;  esta actividad y agregándole la venta D. mercancías les ha ayudado a  ella y a su esposo a progresar, porque  dedicados a apoyar la educación D. sus hijos, los llevaron hasta el bachillerato y aun a hacer carreras técnicas, en las que ahora trabajan y les aportan una cantidad D. dinero mensual para su sostenimiento; ella dice,  que con su negocio consiguieron comprar la vivienda  y que su sueño ahora, es que sus hijos siempre tengan un mejor  empleo y ampliar el negocio hasta conseguir que este sea un almacén,  lo cual le generaría mucha  satisfacción personal.  Teresa Vive en el barrio Ciudadela 20 D. Julio, nombre que indica una relación histórica con su país, pues justamente  fue inaugurado el 20 D. julio, día en que se celebra la independencia D. Colombia y donD. se realizan eventos deportivos, culturales D. origen patriótico.
texts.en:
Teresa D. Jesús Márraga, 59, lives in Barranquilla’s La Ciudadela 20 D. Julio neighborhood. She has 5 children that range in ages from 30 to 39. She sells general merchandise and prepared meals, especially breakfasts and candy. She is asking Fundación Mario Santo Domingo for her 15th loan valued at $2.000.000 to buy merchandise such as, clothing, shoes, items, and appliances to meet customer demand. She came from SabanagranD. at the age of 20. She was only able to finish third graD. because, when her father died, four of her six sisters had to go to work as domestic employees to support the household. One day, however, her mother suggested they start a business and, taking her experience cooking started to sell meals and pastries, an activity that continues to this day. This activity, plus the added sales of merchandise, helped her and her husband to progress. They succeeded in educating their children through high school even completing technical careers in which they now work; they contribute certain monthly amounts to help with their support. She says that their business maD. it possible for them to buy a house and that her dream now is that her children always have good jobs and to enlarge the business until it can become a store which would be of great personal satisfaction to her. Teresa lives in the Ciudadela 20 D. Julio neighborhood, a name that points to a historical relationship with her country because it was inaugurated on July 20th, Colombia’s Independence Day. It is here that patriotic athletic and cultural events take place.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing, shoes, items and appliances.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy rice, soap, cooking oil and sugar in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase merchandise to stock her business selling groceries.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy beans, rice and salt in bulk to sell to her customers

loans.name: Creciendo Juntos 2&3 Group

texts.en:
Frank, 63, lives in El Seybo, Dominican Republic. He leads a loan group called Creciendo Juntos (Growing Together), and his story is typical of this group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Frank lives on his own in a simple home in El Seybo, a small rural town in the agricultural east of the Dominican Republic. Life in rural areas of the Dominican Republic can be hard, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate access to healthcare, among other problems. Despite these difficulties, Frank runs a successful “colmado”, or small corner store. In colmados, people sell anything from bread to batteries. They are a staple of Dominican culture, a place that most local people visit daily. He will use this loan to buy perfume and food such as rice and beans to sell to his customers at a small markup. This is Frank’s fifth loan with Esperanza International. Frank hopes to continue the growth of his business, and dreams of buying a home in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic. 

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families from poverty through initiatives that generate income, education and health, and restore self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in 11 offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Frank and the Creciendo Juntos group!

loans.use: To buy food and perfume to sell to his customers

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is a 52-year-old widow with five children. Since her husband’s death, she has cared for her children alone and worked hard to ensure that she meets their basic needs. Patience makes a living selling second-hand refrigerators at retail prices to her customers, who are usually friends and neighbors. She needs a loan for NGN 50,000 to buy more second-hand refrigerators to sell. She extends sincere thanks to all Kiva lenders for their help and support.

loans.use: To buy more second-hand refrigerators to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more clothing in bulk to sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more vitenge and kanga in bulk.

loans.name: Women Of Progress Group

texts.en:
Sarkor M. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Women Of Progress. He is 62 years old, single, and has ten children who range from 9 to 34 years old. He is a college graduate with a bachelor degree.

For 3 years, Sarkor has been selling general goods such as tissues and candles at the West Point Market close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He sells good quality products, which keeps customers returning. He started selling with 700 Liberian Dollars as working capital, and now has 8,000 Liberian Dollars as working capital.

Sarkor plans to use his 10,400 Liberian dollar portion of this 52,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more tissues, candles and rice. His goal is to grow his business into a shop.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Sarkor is the one holding the sign. Comfort M. is inset on the lower right.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more tissues, candles and rice.

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Sabina B. prepares kenkey for sale at Elmina. She is married and has three children. Sabina has received a junior high education. Her husband is an internal car decorator. With the income she gets from her sales, she supports her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be added to her initial capital to buy more corn for the making of kenkey. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to enhance her children’s education.

To prepare her kenkey she buys maize from the market, soaks it in a lot or enough water to soften the maize. She washes it on the third day and sends it to the mill to be milled. She then makes a mixture of dough out of the milled wet corn, leaves it to proof until the next day. She divides the proofed dough into two, uses one for her firm half-cooked dough (mixes it with water to get it into a porridge form, cooks it for some time to get a firm mixture or texture of the dough) and mixes the rest of the uncooked one with the half cooked. She moulds them into balls and raps them in corn husk. She then cooks them again until it becomes soft to eat.

Kenkey can be eaten with various kinds of sauces such as pepper sauce with fried or roasted fish, roasted chicken, roasted turkey and any other kind of meat or fish.

She is demonstrating how the corn dough is mixed.

loans.use: Her loan will be added to her initial capital to buy more corn for the making of kenkey.

loans.name: Fe En Dios Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “FE EN DIOS”, actualmente se encuentra en el III ciclo, las reuniones D. los socios son cada treinta días en la oficina central D. la Asociación Arariwa, el banco comunal esta conformado por 10 personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos, es un banco comunal conformado por socios que viven en la ciudad del Cusco. Cusco es una cuidad que se caracteriza por su centros arqueológicos, su centro histórico,  sus paisajes, su historia, siendo una ciudad encantadora D. la Región Sur del país.

Las actividades eco nómicas D. los socios a las que se dedican son por ejemplo, producción D. joyas D. oro y plata, administrador D. un súper mercado, venta D. joyas al por mayor y menor, confección D. chompas, venta D. cosméticos, venta D. comida, venta D. productos esotéricos, venta D. artesanía y otros ofrecen servicios D. seguridad. El banco comunal tiene varios ciclos D. funcionamiento, como manifiestan las socias, se encuentran contentas y satisfechas con los servicios D. crédito, ahorro y capacitación, por el tiempo D. permanencia en el banco comunal un aspecto D. valoración es el ahorro por la posibilidad D. capitalización que les brinda este servicio. 

Yomira forma parte del banco comunal “Fe en Dios”, ella tiene 32 años D. edad, ella nació en la ciudad D. Puno, ella tiene dos hijos y se llaman Luís Marcelo y Bryham D. la cuales los dos dependen todavía D. ella, ella nos cuenta que es madre y padre para sus hijos pues no recibe apoyo D. su pareja. Yomira alterna sus actividades del hogar con sus actividades comerciales como por ejemplo venta D. casacas, venta D. ropa y venta D. zapatos. Ella nos cuenta que las casacas que venden son exportadas D. país D. Argentina y los ofrece a las instituciones publicas y los zapatos los trae D. la ciudad D. Puno y los ofrece a las vendedoras D. los mercados D. la ciudad. Yomira también nos cuenta que hace poco termino D. estudiar cosmetología y el préstamo que requiere es para abrir una tienda spa y boutique. Ya son 12 años que trabaja con los bancos solidarios y con la Asociación  Arariwa 2 años y le ha ido muy bien gracias a la responsabilidad que le caracteriza.    

Los socios en general agradecen la oportunidad brindada y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago D. sus diferentes cuotas en los plazos establecidos.
texts.en:
The communal bank "FE EN DIOS" (Faith in God) is in its third cycle. The member meetings are every 30 days in the main office of the Asociación Araiwa. The communal bank is maD. up of 10 hard working and entrepreneurial people who are always looking for ways to get ahead, and with their daily efforts proviD. a better future to their children. It is a communal bank maD. up of members who live in the city of Cuzco. Cuzco is a city characterized by its archeological centers, its historic center, its landscapes, and history. It is an enchanting city in the southern region of the country. The economic activities of the members are, for example: production of gold and silver jewelry, manager of a supermarket, wholesale and retail jewelry sales, production of sweaters, cosmetics sales, food sales, sales of esoteric products, sales of handicrafts, and others offer security services. The communal bank has been together for a number of cycles. The members are happy and satisfied with the loans, savings and training provided. Due to the amount of time they have been with the communal bank, they are able to earn valuable compound interest on their savings. Yomira is part of the communal bank "Fe en Dios". She is 32 years old. She was born in the city of Puno. She has two sons named Luís Marcelo and Bryham, both of whom she supports. She is both mother and father to her children as she does not receive support from her partner. Yomria alternates between her domestic work and commercial activities such as selling jackets, clothes, and shoes. The jackets she sells are exported from Argentina and she sells them to the public. She brings shoes form Puno and sells them to vendors in the city markets. Yomira recently finished studying cosmetology and the loan she is requesting is to open a boutique and spa. She has been working with banks for 12 years and with the Asociación Arariwa for 2 years, and things have gone very well thanks to her responsible nature. The members are thankful for this opportunity and promise to make their respective payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Yomira  is requesting the loan to open a boutique and spa.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more maize, rice and beans in bulk.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice C. is 37 years old and married to Joseph C., who is a businessman. They have three children: Chesire, (12 yrs: Class 6); Chebaskwony, (9 yrs: Class 4); and Kiprono (2 yrs). They live in Timboiywo Village.

Alice is a farmer and she has been farming since 2000. Her farm is in an area called Timboiywo where most of her customers are residents. She gets a profit of Kshs 4000 per month from this business.

Alice was introduced to KADET by her friends and she has never borrowed a loan from any other micro finance institution. She has borrowed an educational loan of Kshs 30,000, which she will use to pay for the school fees for her children.  

She expects to get a bumper harvest this season and she plans to utilize the profits from this farm produce well. She dreams of having a big farm in the future, educating her children to the highest level possible. and having a stable source of income.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Eliud

texts.en:
Eliud is 61 years old, married to Jane Njoki, and they have two grown-up children who already have their own families. He has run his agro-vet shop in Naivasha town for the last year.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend. He has applied for a loan which he will use to increase capital for his operations, since he plans to add stock of maize seedlings and pesticide for sale in his shop.

He plans to enlarge his agro-vet shop and supply and sell his products both wholesale and retail.

loans.use: To buy maize seedlings in bulk and pesticides to sell.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy is a fashion designer and she also sells sarongs and tailoring materials. She makes lovely Nigerian and western designs for her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She is 36 years old, is married with 5 children, and her husband also works to support the home. She hopes to have a fashion shop in the future. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more sarongs and tailoring materials to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and tailoring materials to sell.

loans.name: Scheylis Maria

texts.es:
Scheylis V. tine 27 anos y un hijo de seis meses de edad, vive en ciudad modesto, un barrio del sur occidente de Barranquilla, donde inicio su negocio de ofrecer  servicios de video juegos, el cual está  registrado en la Cámara de Comercio con el nombre de  Video juegos S y K; ella comenzò esta actividad, cuando quedo sin su trabajo de vendedora en una empresa y con el dinero producto de su liquidación, se ubicò inicialmente en la casa de su hermana y luego en el sitio que en la actualidad se encuentra, muy cerca a la via principal, lo cual hace que su negocio sea muy reconocido. Scheylis ha dado a su negocio un énfasis educativo, por eso su mayor mercado son los hijos de sus vecinas, que muchas veces dejan en el local a sus hijos menores,  para que se diviertan,  pues a Sheilys le tienen mucha confianza porque conocen que le encanta trabajar con niños y los cuida y protege.
Scheylis  le recomendó su madre que accediera a créditos con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo  porque ella también es negociante y participò con esta organizaciòn, cuando la apoyò para hacer mejoramiento locativo. En la actualidad  Scheylis aplica para un financiamiento  por valor de $2.000.000 para comprar nuevos juegos y si es posible un computador, que le dé un sentido más moderno a su negocio y los niños o jóvenes aprendan mientras se divierten.
Su meta es ampliar su negocio, ofrecer mayor comodidad, apoyarse con promociones para atraer mas clientela especialmente en fechas como  las  vacaciones escolares,  donde los niños visitan  menos su negocio y también quiere mas adelante adecuarlo, con mas computadores y poder acceder, en la red de internet, donde puede ofrecer juegos muy modernos, que diviertan a la familia en general e interactivos.
Su mayor desafío fue pasar de empleada a trabajadora independiente, cuando la necesidad de responder a su pequeño hijo y la falta de empleo la llevaron a montar este negocio, pero ahora se siente muy a gusto, porque tiene tiempo para atender a sus bebe y realizar otras actividades simultaneas a su trabajo.  
Su negocio està rodeado de muchos locales comerciales, donde hay  ferreterías, estaderos, talleres automotriz y se encuentra al lado de la carretera donde trafica mucho transporte publico, que facilita el acceso rápido de sus clientes a su negocio y tambien sus diligencias personales y de su negocio
texts.en:
Scheylis V. is 27 years old and has a 6 month old son. She lives in Ciudad Modesto, a neighborhood in the southwest of Barranquilla, where she started her business offering video games. Her business is registered in the Chamber of Commerce with the name Video Juegos S y K. She started this business when she lost her job as a salesperson. With her severance payment she initially set up her business in her sister’s house, and later in its current location, very close to the main road, so her business is very well known. Scheylis has put an educational emphasis on her business, because her largest market is the neighbors' children. They often leave their younger children there so that they can play. They trust Scheylis because they know she loves to work with children and she cares for and protects them. Her mother, who is also a businesswoman and participates in this organization, recommended that Scheylis request a loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. Scheylis is requesting a loan for $2.000.00 to purchase new games and possibly a computer, which will modernize her business and enable the children and young people to learn while they have fun. Her goal is to expand her business, make it more comfortable, and offer promotions to attract new customers especially during school vacations when she has fewer customers. In the future she also wants to improve her business by adding more computers and internet access, where she can offer more modern games which entertain the whole family and are interactive. Her greatest challenge was to go from being an employee to an independent worker when the need to support her small child and a lack of work drove her to start this business. She now enjoys it because she has time to care for her baby and to do other things while she is working. Her business is surrounded by many other businesses, such as hardware stores, ballrooms, and auto shops. It is also next to the highway where there is a lot of public transportation, which provides easy access for her customers, and for her personal and business errands.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase modern games

loans.name: María Margarita

texts.es:
María Margarita R. M. tiene 65 años y cuatro hijos que ya no dependen de ella. Su negocio consiste en la venta de flores en su puesto en una plazoleta al frente del Cementerio Universal de Barranquilla. Se vinculó a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo hace 11 años cuando fue promocionada por un asesor que la observaba y veía su desempeño. Con el crédito de $1.600.000 que ahora solicita, quiere surtirse con flores artificiales y naturales  como anturios, rosas, capullos, claveles y orquídeas que consigue más económicamente en Maicao, una ciudad fronteriza cerca de Venezuela.
El negocio de María en la venta flores surgió después de que abandonó la venta de mercancías que tenía en Maicao, municipio de donde vino a Barranquilla por cuestiones de seguridad. Inició su negocio de vender flores con una amiga que era la capitalista y obtenían iguales utilidades después de la venta. Como esto la favorecía, decidió independizarse y durante sus once años con la Fundación ha tenido mucho éxito en su negocio. Dice que su mayor desafío es la competencia que le hacen otras personas a quienes las ha enseñado María cómo vender flores. Antes se sentaba en su carpa esperando que la gente la fuera a buscar, pero ahora busca a sus clientes alrededor del cementerio, hecho que la ha ayudado conservarlos y a promover bien su negocio; el resultado es que se le acerca gente, incluso de otros departamentos de Colombia, que tiene sus seres queridos en otros cementerios pero le tienen mucha confianza, pues sabe cómo conservar  las flores. Sus éxitos la ayudan a realizar sus sueños, de los cuales el principal es el de tener un mayor capital para surtir el negocio, sobre todo con flores naturales.
texts.en:
María Margarita R. M. is 65 years old and has four children who no longer depend on her. She sells flowers at her stall in the square in front of the Universal Cemetery of Barranquilla. She began to work with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo 11 years ago when a consultant observed her and saw her performance. With the loan of 1,600 Colombian pesos she is asking for, she wants to stock up with artificial and fresh flowers like anthuriums, roses, flower buds, carnations and orchids, which she can get more economically in Maicao, a border city near Venezuela. María's flower sales business came into being after she abandoned the merchandise sales she had done in Maicao and moved to Barranquilla for security reasons. She began her business selling flowers with a friend who had the capital, and they got equal profits after the sale. As this went well for her, she decided to become independent, and during her eleven years with the Fundación she has had much success with her business. She says that her greatest challenge is the competition she gets from other people whom María has taught how to sell flowers. She used to sit in her tent waiting for people to come look for her, but now she looks for her customers around the cemetery, which has helped her to keep those customers and promote her business; the result is that people come to her, even people from other departments in Colombia whose loved ones are in other cemeteries. They have a lot of confidence in her since she know how to preserve flowers Her successes help her to make her dreams come true, and her main dream is to have more capital to supply her business, especially with fresh flowers.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock artificial and fresh flowers like anthuriums, roses, flower buds, carnations and orchids

loans.name: Trinidad 	Aleida

texts.es:
La Sra. Trinidad es Madre soltera tiene una pequeña hija, tiene como actividad la peluqueria atendiendo en su salon que tiene en la zona de sopocachi, es la segunda ves que  recibe un credito bajo este programa, ella esta muy agradecida con emprender ya que pudo crecer en su empresa ya que es un apoyo al ingreso de su familia, por que ella vive con su madre y su pequeña hija.
El destino del credito sera para la compra de dos lava cabezas y refaccionar su salon de belleza. es un apersona responsable y trabajadora nunca tobo problemas en el pago de sus cuotas, uno de sus deseos es de ver a su hija profesional y tambien formar pronto una familia y asi dar a su pequeña hija una estabilidad familiar.
texts.en:
Trinidad is the single mother of a young daughter, and her business is a beauty salon that she tends to in the Sopocachi zone. This is the second time she is receiving a loan through this program. She is very grateful for the assistance as it helped her grow her business, which helps provide towards the family’s income since she lives with her mother and daughter. The loan will be used to buy two hair-washing sinks and to refurbish her salon. She is a very responsible and hard-working person, who never had any problems with her loan payments. She hopes to see her daughter become a professional, and to soon have a complete family in order to provide more stability for her daughter.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To refurbish her beauty salon and buy hair-washing sinks.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy sells groceries, drinks and sachet water at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business since 2000. Mercy is single without children and she is 31 years old. She is a bini by tribe. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more drinks and sachet water to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and sachet water to sell.

loans.name: Milka

texts.en:
Milka is 37 years old, married to Nicholas Waweru, and they have six children who all go to school. She works as a tailor and has been running her tailoring shop in Naivasha town for the last eight years. She specializes in making new clothes for sale by order, but she can also repair torn clothes for her clients at a small fee.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her second loan from the institution. She had earlier applied for a loan of Kshs 50,000 which she paid well and on time. She plans to buy more textile cloth which she will use to make new clothes for sale.

Her future dream is to continue in tailoring, enlarge her business, and move into a bigger place where she can employ other people to increase her clothes production.

loans.use: To buy textiles for making new clothes for sale.

loans.name: Javier

texts.es:
El señor Javier P. vive en su vivienda propia en la zona de Tacagua, área suburbana de esta ciudad con su esposa y sus dos hijos.
El señor Javier trabaja como tramitador independiente realizando tramites varios en la alcaldía de la ciudad.
El préstamo será destinado a la construcción de un muro divisorio que adecuara su en su vivienda un dormitorio para sus hijos.
Esta es la sexta vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Javier P. lives in his own house with his wife and two children in the Tacagua neighborhood, a suburb of the city. Javier works as an independent contractor handling various transactions in city hall. The loan will be used to build a partition wall to create a bedroom for his children. This is the sixth time he has requested a loan, and his evaluation shows that he qualifies and can take out a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a partition wall to create a bedroom for his children

loans.name: Thérèse

texts.fr: Thérèse M. est une femme de 47 ans, elle mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DAROU-KOUDOSS depuis 3ans et demi. Elle développe un petit commerce de jus de citron et d'huile de palme, elle fait également de l'embouche porcine. Son objectif est d'aider son mari dans la gestion financière de la famille.
texts.en:
Thérèse M. is a 47-year-old woman, married, and mother to six children. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of Darou-Koudoss for three and a half years. She runs a small lemon juice and palm oil business. She also equally is in the swine fattening business. Her goal is to help her husband manage the family's financial needs.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Augmentation of investment capital

loans.name: Emprendedoras 3 Group

texts.en:
Ana, 27, is a borrower who lives in El Seybo, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Emprendedoras (Entrepreneurs), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Ana lives with her husband and three children in a simple home in El Seybo, in the heart of the agricultural east of the Dominican Republic. Life in rural areas of the Dominican Republic can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate access to healthcare, among other dangers. Despite these difficulties, Ana runs a successful business running a small fried food stand in her community. With this loan, she will be purchasing a new stove and a gas tank for her food stand.

This is Ana’s third loan with Esperanza International. With continued profits, Ana hopes to continue the growth of her business. Her business has given her the ability to “supply her children with a healthy lifestyle, keeping them educated and well-fed”. Ana is very grateful for her loans, and hopes that with continued profits she will be able to purchase a refrigerator for her home. Ana’s long-term goal is to one day have her own home, and with a successful business she is well on her way.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Ana and the Emprendedoras group!

loans.use: To buy a stove and gas tank for her fried food stand.

loans.name: James Muigai

texts.en:
James is a 41 year old married father of five children. His primary business is farming and he has been doing this for a number of years now. He sells his farm produce to Githunguri farmer’s co-operative society, and also to other traders who buy and transport the produce to other bigger towns like Nairobi. His wife Joyce is a farmer as well.

He got to know about KADET through marketing that was carried out by the organization in Githunguri center. This is his first loan with KADET though he has a previous credit history. He plans to buy seedlings for kale, coriander, and others for the next planting season.

James hopes to better the living standards of his family, and buy property (land), develop it and rent it out to get more income. He considers himself to be hardworking.

loans.use: To buy seedlings for spinach, kale, coriander and others for his farm.

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
La señora Gregoria Y. vive en casa propia, en la zona  de Pasankeri, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, con sus dos hijos, ya que es madre soltera.
La señora Gregoria es cocinera, vendiendo almuerzos en la parada de transporte publico de su zona. Ingresos con los que mantiene a su familia.
Con el crédito anterior realizo la construcción de techado de dos habitaciones.
El crédito solicitado es para la conclusión de la construcción de las habitaciones que proporcionarán a su familia de ambientes adecuados para su diario vivir.
Esta es la tercera vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Señora Gregoria Y. lives with her two children in her own house in the Pasankeri zone on the west side of the city of La Paz. She is a single mother. Señora Gregoria is a cook, selling lunches at the public transportation stop in her zone and using the income to maintain her family.

With her last loan, she completed the construction of the roof of two rooms. The loan she has applied for is to complete construction of the rooms, which will supply her family with an adequate environment for their daily life.

This is the third time that she has applied for a loan, and the completed socioeconomic analysis qualifies her to be granted the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish two rooms to make her family more comfortable.

loans.name: Hulley

texts.es:
La Sra. Hulley, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Barbará II”  del Distrito de la Banda de Shilcayo, Provincia de San Martín y Departamento de San Martín ,  tiene 25 años , es Casada y madre de 01 que aun depende de ella y esta estudiando.

Hulley, es una mujer que ha podido superar muchas dificultades en su camino de vida, las ganas de salir adelante le dieron muy buenos resultados y hoy en día, se dedica a la venta de carteras y zapatos, ya que habiendo estudiado cursos de manualidades, no dudo en ejercer ese conocimiento e implementar su propio negocio, donde poco a poco fue haciéndose muy conocida entre sus clientes y hoy nos cuenta que le va muy bien en esta actividad. Se encuentra ubicada en un ambiente muy bien acondicionado, en su misma casa, donde atiende a sus clientes, con la amabilidad y carisma, que siempre la ha caracterizado. Con su primer crédito de 300 Nuevos Soles compró, materiales para la elaboración de carteras, zapatos de diferentes.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1000.00, comprará materiales como: Plantas de zapatos , cueros y viocueros ,  lentejuelas , diseños , etc. Parte del dinero también lo invertirá en la compra  de un andamio, donde pueda exhibir sus productos, a sus clientes.
  
Hulley, esta contenta y realizada por cumplir sus sueños y metas, agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
La Sra. Hulley, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Barbará II” del Distrito de la Banda de Shilcayo, Provincia de San Martín y Departamento de San Martín , tiene 25 años , es Casada y madre de 01 que aun depende de ella y esta estudiando. Hulley, es una mujer que ha podido superar muchas dificultades en su camino de vida, las ganas de salir adelante le dieron muy buenos resultados y hoy en día, se dedica a la venta de carteras y zapatos, ya que habiendo estudiado cursos de manualidades, no dudo en ejercer ese conocimiento e implementar su propio negocio, donde poco a poco fue haciéndose muy conocida entre sus clientes y hoy nos cuenta que le va muy bien en esta actividad. Se encuentra ubicada en un ambiente muy bien acondicionado, en su misma casa, donde atiende a sus clientes, con la amabilidad y carisma, que siempre la ha caracterizado. Con su primer crédito de 300 Nuevos Soles compró, materiales para la elaboración de carteras, zapatos de diferentes. Con este préstamo de S/. 1000.00, comprará materiales como: Plantas de zapatos , cueros y viocueros , lentejuelas , diseños , etc. Parte del dinero también lo invertirá en la compra de un andamio, donde pueda exhibir sus productos, a sus clientes. Hulley, esta contenta y realizada por cumplir sus sueños y metas, agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.

Translated from Spanish by Alex Jaffe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprarà materiales para la elaboración de sus carteras y zapatos.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort A. is a single parent living with six dependants. Comfort makes and sells palm kernel oil at Elmina. She has a junior high education. Comfort has been producing palm kernel oil for sale for some time now. She uses her income to feed, clothe and provide shelter for the family. Comfort will add the loan to her money to acquire a palm nut plantation where every fruit harvested on the plantation will belong to her, though she might not be necessarily be the owner of the plot of land. With the new profits from her expanded business, Comfort plans to use it to pay school fees for her dependants.
 
To prepare her palm kernel oil, she shells off the palm nuts. The shelling used to be performed using two stones to crack each nut and separating the kernel and shell simultaneously. This manual operation has been largely superseded by the use of nut-cracking machines.

The traditional oil extraction method is to simply heat the dried nuts to release the palm kernel oil. The released oil is periodically skimmed from the top as the heat is applied. This process is continued until almost all the oil is skimmed out of the palm kernel.

loans.use: To acquire a palm nuts plantation.

loans.name: Karen Mabel

texts.es: La Sra. Karen es Madre Soltera y tiene una pequeña hija, la actividad que tiene es de una pequeña  tienda de barrio en la cual vende distintos productos como ser pan refrescos y conservas esta actividad le permite subsistir a ella y su pequeña hija es la primera ves que solicita un credito y este sera destinado para el aumento de capital de trabajo (compra de mercaderia para su tienda), ella vive aun con sus padres y su pequeña hija de 2 años, ella es una persona joven con ganas de triunfar y salir adelante por el bien de su hija es muy trabajadora ya que tambien esta comenzando con la elboracion de bombones rrellenos de manjar y de crema y ya los esta vendiendo. Esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada.
texts.en:
Karen is a single mother of a young daughter. Her business is tending to her small neighborhood store, where she sells a variety of products such as fresh bread and canned goods. This activity allows her to support herself and her daughter. This is the first time she requests a loan, which will be used to augment her working capital (to purchase merchandise for her store). She still lives with her parents, along with her 2-year old daughter. She is a young woman with a great desire to succeed and get ahead for the sake of her daughter. She is very hard-working, and also is starting to make cream-filled chocolates to sell. She is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence they are showing in her.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase seasonal merchandise.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 27 years old and married to Mary Wangari. He has been operating his motorcycle transport business for one year now, but he also has a business of delivering milk using the motorcycle.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to boost his milk supply business with cash from this loan.

His future dream is to grow his business and be able to enable other people economically by employing them.

loans.use: To boost his milk supply business.

loans.name: Carlos Martin

texts.es: Carlos Martin tiene 37años, por lo que este no es el primer financiamiento que solicita, ya que las experiencias que he tenido le han sido de mucho provecho  por lo que su actividad económica es brindar los servicios de alquiler de molino. Hace más de 7 años que se dedica a este negocio, el inicio por cuenta propia, en estos momentos es un hombre que se preocupa por cumplir sus funciones como padre y esposo al cuidado de sus hijos. Es por ese motivo que solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la proporcionarle el mantenimiento necesario a su molino ya que es muy solicitado por sus clientes que llegan a moler maíz, carne, pinol y pozol. Su mayor deseo obtener otro medio de ingreso para mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Carlos Martin is 37 years old, and thus this is not the first loan he has applied for, since the experiences he has had have been of much benefit. His business is offering the use of a mill for hire. He began this business more than 7 years ago, on his own initiative. At this time he is a man who worries about fulfilling his duties as a father and husband for the care of his children. For this reason he is applying for this loan for working capital to provide the necessary maintenance of his mill, since it is requested by his customers who arrive to grind corn, meat, grains, and pozol. His greatest desire is to obtain another means of income to improve his living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Blossom

texts.en: Blossom is a 32 year old woman who is married with 3 children. Her husband is a fashion designer. Blossom renders laundry services to her customers. She started this business a year ago. Her major challenge is funds and she hopes to overcome that challenge. She hopes to own a classic laundry company in the future. Blossom hopes for a loan amount of NGN 120,000 to purchase more laundry equipment to boost her business. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more laundry equipment to boost her business.

loans.name: Dieynaba

texts.fr: Dieynaba D. est une femme de 54 ans, elle est veuve et vit avec ses 3 enfants dont elle a l'entière charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DAROU-KHOUDOSS depuis 3ans et demi et y a bénéficié de 7 prêts. Elle développe un petit commerce de légumes, d'épices et de bouillons. Elle vend ses produits sur étalage au marché de son quartier. Son objectif est de subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants et de leurs assurer un bien-être familiale.
texts.en:
Dieynaba D. is a 54-year-old woman, a widow who lives with her three children whom she supports by herself. She has been a member of the "Banc Villegeois" of Darou-Khoudoss for three and a half years, and she has received seven loans. She is building a small business selling vegetables, spices, and bouillons (dried soup stock). She sells her products on shelves at her neighborhood market. Her goal is to meet her children's needs and ensure her family's well-being.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build her investment capital

loans.name: Ewoi

texts.en:
Ewoi is 48 years old, married to Pauline Atabo, and they have four children. He has been selling charcoal in small quantities in Naivasha town for the last four years.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy 2 more sacks of charcoal, which he will divide and sell in small quantities to his neighbors.

He plans to start selling cereals on the side in the near future to increase his income.

loans.use: To buy two sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more soda, rice, cooking oil, and sugar in bulk.

loans.name: Carmen Esther

texts.es:
Carmen Esther es una mujer proactiva, a sus 37 años, es casada, tiene 4 hijos de 18, 16, 5 y uno que recién acaba de nacer, trabaja con EDAPROSPO prosperidad desde hace 5 años, se dedica a la venta de CD, MP3, VCD, desde hace 10 años,  además vende flores artificiales, desde hace 4 meses, el cual lleva por nombre “ROSAS”, y recientemente acaba de inaugurar una cabina de internet el cual lo puso con el desembolso de diciembre del 2009, con el esfuerzo de su labor diaria ha logrado dar una mejor educación a sus hijos, ha comprado un repostero, una computadora, ha hecho el piso de su vivienda, y ha mejorado su calidad de vida. 
El gran sueño de Carmen, es mejorar el acabado de su vivienda y comprarse un carro para movilizar su mercadería. El reciente préstamo otorgado será invertido en la compra cuadros locerías y habilitar mas cabinas de internet. Carmen se encuentra muy agradecida por todo el apoyo brindado, porque le ha ayudado  a salir adelante y a prosperar con su familia.
texts.en:
Carmen Esther is a proactive woman. She is 37 years old and married, with four children ages 18, 16, and 5, and a newborn. She has worked with EDAPROSPO Prosperity for 5 years. She has sold CDs, MP3s, and DVDs for 10 years. In addition, four months ago she began selling artificial flowers, which go by the name "rosas." She just recently opened an internet kiosk, which she set up with the December 2009 disbursement. With the force of her daily labor, she has succeeded in giving her children a better education, she has bought a pastry shop and a computer, she has put a floor in her home, and she has improved her quality of life. Carmen's great dream is to improve the finishing of her home and buy a car to carry her merchandise. The recently granted loan will be invested in the purchase of dishes and pictures and in setting up more internet kiosks. Carmen is very appreciative of all the support offered, because it has helped her and her family advance and prosper.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: by pictures, dishes, and set up more internet kiosks

loans.name: Cheikh

texts.fr: Cheikh T. est une femme de 67 ans, elle est veuve et mère de 5 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DAROU-KOUDOSS depuis 2ans et demi et a eu 5 expériences avec le crédit. Avec son nouveau prêt elle va développer un petit commerce de pâte d'arachide, de poivre, d'ail, de sel etc. Son objectif est de satisfaire les besoins de ses enfants et de leur assurer un avenir meilleur par la prise en charge de leur scolarité.
texts.en:
Cheikh T. is a 67 years old woman. She is a widow and a mother providing for five children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" Darou-Koudoss for two and half years. She has had five experiences with loans. With her new loan she will develop a small retail business of peanut butter, pepper, garlic, salt, etc. Her goal is to meet the needs of her children and to ensure them a better future by providing for their schooling fees.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To promote her small retail business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more used clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Deborah is 48 years old, married to Joel Mbuthia, and they have three children. She has run her tailoring shop in Njabini town for the last 20 years.  

She is one of the longest serving clients of KADET, and this will be her third loan. She has paid the previous two loans very well and on time and she used the loan amounts to increase her business. She now wants to take her business to another level by building a classroom where she will start tutoring classes on tailoring. This is the reason for applying for a new loan. This will increase her income as she will be charging for those classes.

She plans to develop the school and have a minimum of 100 students every year. She also plans to get contracts from local schools to make school uniforms and sell the uniforms to them at a wholesale price. She plans to employ more people in her tailoring business, thus empowering them financially.

loans.use: To build a room for tailoring classes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more beans, rice, sugar and salt in bulk.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en: Christine is a 51 year old widowed lady. She has been supporting her six children with her knitting and farming business. She knits sweaters and sells milk in schools. She plans to take a loan of Kes.20,000 to add stock of knitting materials. She is determined to see her business grow to a higher level. She sees herself employing many people if her business expands. She describes herself as hardworking, enthusiastic and determined.

loans.use: To add more materials for knitting.

loans.name: Petronila De Los Ángeles

texts.es:
En el Mercado Mayoreo de Managua, la señora Petronila de los ángeles G. es una dama muy trabajadora que se dedica a la actividad de venta de pan viajando a diario al mercado desde el departamento de Carazo específicamente desde Jinotepe.

Es importante destacar que ella vende el pan ambulantemente por todo el mercado exponiéndose al sol y la fatiga de caminar todo el día con el fin de vender el pan y así llevar el sustento a su hogar.

El crédito lo está solicitando para la compra de pan dulce y simple para continuar ofertándolo y así generar ingresos para el mantenimiento de su hogar y así apoyar a su hijo en edad escolar.
texts.en:
Petronila de los Ángeles G. is a hard-working lady at the Mangua Wholesale Market, where she dedicates herself to selling bread. Every day, she travels to the market from the Carazo region or, more specifically, from the city of Jinotepe. It’s important to highlight that she sells her bread on foot throughout the market, exposing herself to the sun and to fatigue from walking all day long. Her goal is to sell her bread so she can generate income to support her family. The loan she is requesting is for the purchase of sweet and plain breads to sell. This way, she can support her household and her school-aged child.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sweet and plain breads.

loans.name: Claudia Veronica

texts.es:
Claudia  tiene 21 años de edad, es soltera y vive en casa de sus abuelos, ubicada en el pueblo joven San Martin, una zona urbano marginal de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace más de un año se dedica a la venta de productos cosméticos a través de catálogos, empezó el negocio debido a la necesidad de obtener ingresos económicos que le permitan solventar sus gastos personales y apoyar al sostenimiento de su familia. Durante este tiempo ha venido trabajando con mucho esfuerzo y ha ido incrementando su nivel de ventas, actualmente ya tiene una cartera de clientes que siempre le piden productos.

Claudia desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de productos a precios de oferta para posteriormente venderlos a mejores precios y así obtener mayores ganancias, por ese motivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr sus objetivos

Claudia es una joven bastante empeñosa y trabajadora. Sus clientes prefieren acudir a ella debido a su responsabilidad y compromiso con las labores que realiza. Su mayor anhelo es poder brindarle a sus abuelos una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Claudia is 21 years old, single, and lives with her grandparents in the town of San Martin, a suburb of the City of Chiclayo. For the past year she’s been selling cosmetics through catalogs. She started this business out of necessity for generating an income, which she needed for her personal expenses and to contribute to her family’s support. She’s been putting a lot of effort into her work, and has been improving her sales. She now has steady customers who request her products. Claudia would like to expand her business by buying items at sale prices and reselling them, thus increasing her income. In order to help her meet her objective, she has seen fit to request this first loan of 1,000 PEN ($375) through Edpyme Alternativa. Claudia is very persistent and hard working. Her customers prefer to deal with her because of her responsibility and commitment to her work. Her greatest desire is to provide a better quality of life for her grandparents.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Credit to buy raw materials.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more sugar, rice and salt in bulk

loans.name: Monicah

texts.en: Monicah is 33 years old and married. She is a hardworking woman who has been operating a beauty shop for three years.  She sells cosmetics and clothes to area residents.   She wants to take out her first loan of KES 80,000 from Faulu Kenya to increase her stock of clothes and cosmetics.  She hopes that this loan will help her to have a well-established business.  She sees herself owning a big beauty shop and a boutique in the future.

loans.use: to increase her stock of cosmetics and clothes

loans.name: Ndèye

texts.fr: Ndèye M. est âgée de 50 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants et responsable de la garde de 5 autres enfants qui lui sont confiés par ses proches et parents. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 3ans et demi et a 7 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit. Elle développe un petit commerce de poissons frais et de crème glacée. Son objectif est de participer à la prise en charge de sa famille.
texts.en:
Ndèye M. is 50 years old, married and the mother of four children. She also takes care of five other children entrusted to her by friends and family. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois for three and a half years and obtained seven successive loans in the past. She runs a small business selling fresh fish and ice cream. Her goal is to help with the family expenses.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthening her business

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.es:
La Sra. Candelaria, tiene 35 años, vive en el Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín y Departamento de San Martín. La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Valerosas II”, tiene 03 hijos que aun dependen de ella y están estudiando. 
 Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en general, ya tiene buen tiempo en este negocio y le va bien. El negocio está ubicado en su propia casa lugar donde acuden diariamente sus clientes fijos, amigos del barrio, vecinos y moradores.
Con este préstamo de S/. 2,300 Nuevos Soles, comprará abarrotes en general cómo arroz y azúcar en sacos, leche, aceite, conservas en cajas de diferentes tamaños, papel higiénico en paquetes, detergentes, jabones de diferentes aromas y parte del dinero lo invertirá en frutas y verduras, para dejar satisfecha a su clientela. 
Candelaria, es una mujer trabajadora, carismática y con muchas ganas de seguir trabajando con el negocio porque le gusta lo que hace, su meta es continuar con el negocio. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir en ella y en otras mujeres que lo necesitan.
texts.en:
La Sra. Candelaria, tiene 35 años, vive en el Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín y Departamento de San Martín. La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Valerosas II”, tiene 03 hijos que aun dependen de ella y están estudiando. Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en general, ya tiene buen tiempo en este negocio y le va bien. El negocio está ubicado en su propia casa lugar donde acuden diariamente sus clientes fijos, amigos del barrio, vecinos y moradores. Con este préstamo de S/. 2,300 Nuevos Soles, comprará abarrotes en general cómo arroz y azúcar en sacos, leche, aceite, conservas en cajas de diferentes tamaños, papel higiénico en paquetes, detergentes, jabones de diferentes aromas y parte del dinero lo invertirá en frutas y verduras, para dejar satisfecha a su clientela. Candelaria, es una mujer trabajadora, carismática y con muchas ganas de seguir trabajando con el negocio porque le gusta lo que hace, su meta es continuar con el negocio. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir en ella y en otras mujeres que lo necesitan.

Translated from Spanish by Alex Jaffe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprará abarrotes en general.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas is a 37-year-old married man who has been operating a butcher shop for the past nine years. He was employed before he started his own business. He farms to earn extra income and his wife is a businesswoman.  Nicholas has requested a loan of KES 60,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy goats and cows for slaughter. He hopes to invest his money and buy a plot of land in the future. He dreams of opening other outlets for his business to earn more income.

loans.use: to buy goats and cows for slaughter

loans.name: Clotilde

texts.es:
La señora Clotilde es una mujer emprendedora, tiene 42 años, es casada, tiene 3 hijos, de 21 (casado), 15 y de un año y cuatro meses, se dedica a la venta diaria de ropa, (como ambulante), en la estación de verano a la venta de refrescos de fruta (chicha, maracuyá) y por las noches a la venta de pollo brosther, desde hace 20 años.
Clotilde nos cuenta que los préstamos le han sido de mucha ayuda, ya que ha logrado mejorar su vivienda, ha comprado artefactos y una moto taxi, sus ingresos cubren los gastos de pago de servicios, y el capital que resta lo invierte en su negocio. El gran sueño de Clotilde es tener una tienda de ropa. El reciente préstamo otorgado será invertido para comprar accesorios de moto taxi (puertas, kit de retroceso). Clotilde agradece toda la ayuda que le han dado porque gracias a eso ha salido adelante, por eso es responsable con sus créditos, ha crecido y sigue creciendo junto con su familia y también  como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Clotilde is an enterprising woman. She is 42 years old, is married, and has three children; ages 21 (married), 15, and 1 year, four months. She sells clothing daily (on foot). In the summer station she also sells fruit drinks (chicha, and maracuyá) and in the evenings she sells roast chicken. She’s been doing this for 20 years. Clotilde tells us that the loans have helped her make improvements to her home, helped her buy artifacts, and buy a moto taxi. Her income is enough to cover her service payments. Whatever capital is left over, she reinvests in her business. Cliotilde would like to have a clothing store some day. The money from this loan will be used to buy mototaxi accessories (doors, backup kit). She appreciates all the help that she has been given. Thanks to it, she has come out ahead. This is why she is responsible with her loans. She has grown and continues to grow, along with her family and as a small business woman.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Mototaxi parts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more bags of maize and beans in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more beans, rice, sugar and salt in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more drinks in bulk

loans.name: Penda

texts.fr: Penda S. est une femme de 48 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 7 enfants en charge. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 3ans et demi et a eu 7 expériences avec le crédit. Elle est vendeuse de légumes (choux pommés, manioc, tomate, piment et oignon) Son activité lui génère des bénéfices qui lui permettent de participer à la prise en charge de sa famille et au payement de la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
Penda S. is a 48-year old woman; she is married and a mother providing for seven children. She has been a member of a "Banc Villageois" for three and half years and has received seven loans. She sells vegetables (cabbages, manioc [cassava root], tomatoes, hot peppers, onions). Her activity generates a profit, which allows her to participate in the support of her family and to pay for the children's school fees.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To promote her retail business

loans.name: Magnolias Exitosas Group

texts.en:
This group is called “Magnolia Exitosas” and is made up of 12 members who live in the city of Orizaba (nicknamed “ahullizapan” – a place where the waters are happy). The city is located 1236 meters (4055 feet) above sea level. The state of VeraC., Mexico is characterized by its rainy season, which lasts for most of the year. This is good for the cultivation of chayote squash, sugar cane, and other fruits that need lots of humidity. The members of the group do different things, such as the sale of snacks, tortillas, dietary supplements, yogurt, etc. Among them is Teresa, who is 46 years old, married, and has three children, ages, 21, 16, and 13. She makes school uniforms, typical outfits, and outfits for school dances. She started this business 20 years ago with a sewing machine that she inherited from her mother. Now she has two others that she picked up and she and her niece make the uniforms. She is asking for this loan so that she can buy fabric to make the products she sells. According to her, the biggest accomplishment of the business is that she is able to offer the uniforms at 20% less than can be bought in stores, and with better quality of fabric and workmanship. She hopes that over time, her earnings will allow her to buy two more sewing machines and be able to offer work in her shop to other people. She is also paying for her oldest son’s university education, because in her words, “she wants to give him the basis with which to face the future.” The other members of the group are: Marisela: Food sales Irasema: Beauty salon Graciela: Food sales Josefina: Snack sales Liliana: Snack sales María: Snack sales Ana: Natural herbs Alfonsina: Tortilla sales Karen: Cleaning supply sales María: Cosmetic sales Celia: Tortilla sales ; CELIA S. S., VENTA DE TORTILLAS.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo R., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies

loans.name: Misioneras Group

texts.es:
La asociación comunal "Las Misioneras de La Cascada" son parte del centro focal de la Cascada, desean iniciar su primer ciclo como asociación comunal.
Son once mujeres las integrantes de la asociación comunal Las Misioneras, en la foto falta la señora Martha O. quien tuvo que ir a recoger a su pequeña hija del colegio.
Los negocios que han declarado las socias son: venta de ropa, venta de verduras, venta de gelatina, venta de calzados, venta de comida, venta de pollo frito, tienda de barrio y encuadernación.
La señora María Antonieta A. es la presidenta de la asociación, con 53 años de edad ella está  llena de energía y buen ánimo;  casada, durante su matrimonio tuvo 7 hijos, de los cuales ahora 5 ya están casados y 2 aún solteros, están bajo su cuidado.  El negocio que desarrolla es el de vender ropa a pedido, es decir que ella compra la ropa que le piden sus clientes, al contado y lo dá a sus clientes en vaR. pagos con un pequeño interés. Este negocio le fue enseñado por un familiar.  Su solicitud para este ciclo es de Bs.2000.- y le servirá para responder con rapidez a los pedidos que reciba de sus clientes.  Ella refiere que tiene clientes en la zona donde vive y también, en otras zonas en la ciudad de El Alto y La Paz.
Cuando ya tiene los pedidos, viaja al Departamento de Oruro para hacer una compra por mayor o si los pedidos son pocos se dirige a La Ciudad de La Paz.
texts.en:
The communal association "Las Misioneras de La Cascada" is part of the focal center of la Cascada. They wish to start their first cycle as a communal association. There are eleven women who are members of the "Misioneras" communal association. Missing in the photo is Martha O. who had to go to collect her young daughter from school. The businesses that the members have stated are: sale of clothing, vegetables, jelly, shoes, food, fried chicken, a neighborhood shop and bookbinding. María Antonieta A. is the president of the association. She is 53 years old and is full of energy and good cheer. She is married with 7 children from this marriage, 5 who are already married and 2 that are still single and under her care. The business that she is developing is selling clothes to order, which means she buys clothes that her clients ask her for, with cash and she charges her clients in several payments with a little interest. She was taught this business by a relative. Her request for this cycle is for Bs.2000.- and to service it she will respond quickly to the orders that she receives from her clients. She says that she has clients in the area where she lives and also in other areas of the city of El Alto and La Paz. When she has enough orders, she travels to the Oruro department to purchase wholesale or if the orders are small she goes to La Paz city.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothes to order

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Benkan comprend dix femmes, deux veuves et huit mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne 36ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent le village de Téssérèla chef lieu d’une commune rurale de la préfecture de Barouéli (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Ce groupe de femmes fait essentiellement le commerce d’articles divers  tels les céréales, les condiments alimentaires, les savons etc.
Dans le souci d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce  elles décident de collaborer avec  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles sont à leur 1er prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter,  2 sacs de riz, 10 sacs de mil, 5 sacs de sorgho, 3 sacs de haricot, 10 sacs d’arachide en gousse, des condiments : 2 sacs de gombo sec, 3 paniers de tomates fraîches, 2 sacs d’oignon frais, 2 sacs de savon local pour la lessive et la vaisselle dont 1sac de « Gabacourouni ». 
Elles s’approvisionnent  à Ségou, sur place à Téssérèla, dans les villages  environnants et à la foire hebdomadaire de N’Gassola.  Les ventes se font à domicile, aux foires hebdomadaires de  N’Gassola et Téssérèla, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22 050FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les prêts de Soro Yiriwaso,  contribuer dans la prise en charge de la santé des enfants et  de leurs frais scolaires.
texts.en:
The Benkan group is made up of ten women, of which two are widowed and the others married, for the most part belonging to traditional extended families, and are on average 36 years old with four children. They live in Téssérèla, the head village of a rural community in the Barouéli prefecture (4th administrative region of Mali). The group’s main activity is retail commerce of various items such as grain cereals, food condiments, soap, etc. Wanting to increase their working capital, they decided to work with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI. They are requesting a first group loan, which will be used to buy: two bags of rice, 10 bags of millet, five bags of sorgho, three bags of beans, 10 bags of unshelled peanuts, condiments (two bags of dried gombo, three baskets of fresh tomatoes, two bags of fresh onions), two bags of local laundry and dishwashing detergent, including one bag of « Gabacourouni » soap. They get their supplies from Segou, locally in Téssérèla and neighboring villages, and from the weekly N’Gassola market fair. They retail their products from their homes, at the weekly market fairs in N’Gassola and Téssérèla, for cash or credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They hope to attain average monthly earnings of 22,050 FCFA each, part of which will be used to reimburse the Soro Yiriwaso loan, and contribute towards the children’s healthcare and tuition costs.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Santos Alberto

texts.es:
El señor Santos Alberto Estrada vive en una casa prE. junto con su esposa y sus dos hijos.
Como desea tener su propia casa vivienda está tramitando una casa por medio de infonavit (Crédito Gubernamental), pero el valor de la vivienda es superior al crédito que el puede recibir ya que su sueldo es bajo.
El trabaja como empleado en una compañía de trasportes. Por tal motivo solicita el préstamo, para completar el crédito gubernamental y así adquirí su casa. Desea tener un patrimonio seguro para su familia.
Las personas que aparecen en la foto son su esposa y sus dos pequeños hijos, ya que el señor Santos Alberto se encontraba en su trabajo, el día de la visita.
texts.en:
Sr. Santos Alberto Estrada lives in a borrowed house with his wife and two children. Because he desires to have his own home, he is in the process of buying a house through INFONAVIT (a government loan program). However, the value of the house is more than the maximum line of credit he is eligible to receive because his salary is low. He works as an employee for a transportation company. For this reason, he is requesting a loan so that he can complete the government program and acquire his house. He desires to build a secure inheritance for his family. The people in the borrower profile are his wife and his two young children. Sr. Santos Alberto was not available to be photographed the day he was visited.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cover the down payment needed to qualify for a government home loan

loans.name: Jojany

texts.en: Jojany, 27, is a borrower who lives in El Seybo, Dominican Republic. She has a perfect repayment history on previous loans and her story is representative of many other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International. Jojany lives with her husband and four children in a simple home in El Seybo, located in the heart of the agricultural east of the Dominican Republic. Life in rural areas of the Dominican Republic can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate access to healthcare, among other dangers. Despite these difficulties, Jojany runs a successful business selling miscellaneous items to the women in her community. With this loan, she plans to purchase women’s blouses, pants and shoes, perfumes, and makeup to sell at a small markup. This is Jojany’s sixth loan with Esperanza International. With continued profits, she hopes to continue the growth of her business. She is very grateful for her loans, noting that she is now confident in the security of her children’s education. With a good education, she knows they will be able to overcome anything. In the long-run, Jojany dreams of having her own home. With her successful store, she is already well on the way. Thank you for your loan to Jojany! About Esperanza International: Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti.

loans.use: To buy women's clothing, perfumes, and makeup to sell

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma es una mujer que lucha día a día por salir adelante, a sus 54 años es casada y tiene 3 hijos, D. 27 (casada), D. 14, y D. 16 años, trabaja con EDAPROSPO – prosperidad desD. hace 8 años, se dedica  a la venta D. condimentos y mercería (peluches y juguetes), desD. hace 14 años, se inicio en este negocio por la necesidad que había en su hogar, con el esfuerzo D. su labor diaria ha amoblado su vivienda.
El gran sueño D. Vilma, es implementar más pisos en su vivienda. El reciente préstamo otorgado será invertido en la compra D. mercadería. Vilma se encuentra muy agradecida por todo el apoyo brindado, porque le ha ayudado  a mejorar su calidad D. vida y el D. sus hijos.
texts.en:
